He is best known for his leading roles in TV dramas such as "My Girl" (2005), "Cinderella's Sister" (2010), and "Sly and Single Again" (2014). He made his acting debut in 2001 in the film "Domani." He rose to fame in the early 2000s with his leading roles in TV dramas such as "Spotlight" (2002), "Night Hospital" (2003), and "Immortal Admiral Yi Sun-sin" (2004). He gained popularity in 2005 for his role in the drama "My Girl," which was a big hit in South Korea. He has since been a well-known actor in South Korea. He was married to actress Kim Ha-neul from 2006 to 2015. He is known to be a hardworking and professional actor who always puts in his best efforts in his work. bio: Kalki Koechlin (born 10 January 1984) is an Indian actress of French descent, who predominantly appears in Hindi films. She was born in Pondicherry, India, to French parents, and was raised primarily in Auroville, an experimental township in southern India. From a young age, Koechlin was drawn to the performing arts and began training in classical dance and theatre. After moving to Mumbai, she made her acting debut with a brief appearance in the film, "Dev D" (2009). She shot to prominence with her critically acclaimed performance in "That Girl in Yellow Boots" (2010). Koechlin has since appeared in numerous notable films, including "Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara" (2011), "Shaitan" (2011), "English Vinglish" (2012), "Happy Ending" (2014), and Netflix's "Smoke and Mirrors" (2015). In addition to her film career, Koechlin has also worked in theater and is an avid blogger. import, export and logistics

bio: William Post, (28 October 1921 - 14 July 2018) was an American neurosurgeon and a pioneer in the field of neurosurgery. He was a professor of neurosurgery at the University of Pittsburgh and also the chief of neurosurgery at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. He was also a member of the Allegheny General Hospital staff. He was known for performing the first surgery of its kind in the US, which involved removing a brain tumor while preserving the brain's blood supply. He was also known for his work in the field of intracranial surgery, particularly for his innovative approaches for treating cranial base tumors. He received a number of awards throughout his career, including the Albert Creasey Award for Clinical Research, the John Gillingham Award for Clinical Excellence, and the Walter E. Dandy Lectureship from the Society of Neurological Surgeons. He also was a member of Alpha Omega Alpha and the International Brain Tumor Society. """"

bio: William Waldegrave, Baron Waldegrave of North Hill (born 26 January 1946) is a British Conservative politician and life peer. He was educated at Eton College and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he received a Master of Arts degree. Waldegrave was elected as Member of Parliament (MP) for Bristol West in February 1973, at the age of 26, he became the youngest Conservative MP in the House of Commons. In 1979, Waldegrave became Parliamentary Private Secretary (PPS) to William Whitelaw, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury. He served as Minister of State for Social Security from 1981 to 1985 and as Minister of State for Health in 1985. Following the Conservative victory in the 1992 general election, Waldegrave was appointed as the Government Chief Whip in the House of Lords. Waldegrave became Secretary of State for Transport in John Major's government in 1995. He served in that role until the Conservative Party lost power in 1997. He was created a life peer as Baron Waldegrave of North Hill on 17 February 2016. bio: Darrius Heyward-Bey (born November 20, 1987) is a former American football wide receiver. He played college football at Maryland and was drafted by the Oakland Raiders in the first round of the 2009 NFL Draft. Heyward-Bey was considered one of the top wide receiver prospects in the draft and was drafted seventh overall. He played for the Raiders for six seasons before being traded to the Indianapolis Colts in 2015 where he played for one season. In 2016, he signed with the Baltimore Ravens but was released during the pre-season. Heyward-Bey is known for his speed and has been timed at 4.26 seconds in the 40-yard dash. In his six years in the NFL, Heyward-Bey caught 252 passes for 3,912 yards and 14 touchdowns.

bio: Andrew Shue (born October 20, 1967) is an American former professional soccer defender and current television producer. He played college soccer at Yale University and was a member of the United States national soccer team from 1988-1991. His professional career included stints with the San Jose Clash and D.C. United in Major League Soccer (MLS) and Wimbledon F.C. in England's Football League First Division. He appeared in three World Cup qualifying matches for the U.S. national team. After retiring from soccer, Shue pursued a career in television production, working on shows such as The L Word and Gossip Girl before co-founding the digital media company The Blaze. He is the director of The Shue Resource, founded in 1994 by his father, Evan Shute. The Shue Resource, based in Washington, D.C., is a private family foundation, the Andrew and Laura Shue Foundation for Autism Awareness, which provides a wide range of information about autism and works to make a positive impact in the autism community. #1 Thing You Can Do Today to Improve Our Relationship with Jesus Christ

bio: Wahida Prism Khan is a Bangladeshi-American film actress and model. She was born in Dhaka, Bangladesh, and later immigrated to the United States with her family. She began her career as a model, appearing in several high-profile advertising campaigns and photo shoots. She made her film debut in the 2011 Bengali film "Bhalo Theko" which was directed by Anjan Dutt. She has since appeared in several Bengali films including "Bhaadra" and "Kagaznagar" and has received critical acclaim for her performances. In addition to her work in films, Khan is also active in the US theater scene and has performed in several Bengali and English-language productions. Khan is also an advocate for women's rights and mental health awareness. package: 48 hours in Amsterdam

bio: Waka Flocka Flame, born Juaquin Malphurs, on May 31, 1986, is an American rapper known for his eccentric and outrageous personality, as well as his unique and hard-hitting style of rapping. He gained mainstream attention with his debut single "O Let's Do It" in 2009, which quickly became a hit and propelled his first studio album, Flockaveli, to platinum status. He has released several successful albums since then, including Hard in the Paint and Triple F Sport, and has collaborated with numerous artists in the industry. Waka Flocka Flame is known for his energetic stage presence, engaging personality, and catchy, club-friendly beats, making him a popular figure in the hip-hop scene. Despite having a few instances of legal trouble in the past, Waka Flocka Flame has built a lasting legacy in the hip-hop world and is respected for his unique sound and style. package: "JOIN BTC GENESIS"

bio: Sara Paxton (born April 25, 1988) is an American actress, model, and singer. She grew up in California and began her acting career at a young age, appearing in various TV shows and films throughout the 1990s and early 2000s. Paxton gained recognition for her role in the 2004 film "A Cinderella Story" as the stepsister of Hilary Duff's character. She has since appeared in various films, including "Last House on the Left" (2009) and "The Innkeepers" (2011). Paxton also starred in the TV series "Aquarius" (2015-2016) and has continued to appear in various TV shows and films, as well as continuing to model and sing. package for "Farming Simulator 17 – “European Farming Experience”

bio: Keita Kadokura (角倉慶太) is a Japanese musician, composer, and sound engineer. He is best known for his work as the lead guitarist for the Japanese rock band The High-Low. The band was formed in 1986 in Tokyo and quickly gained popularity in Japan and Asia. Kadokura was the primary songwriter and musical arranger for the band's songs. He has also worked as a sound engineer and producer for various artists in Japan. Kadokura has released several solo albums and has collaborated with other artists on various projects. His music has been featured in TV dramas, films, and commercials. In addition to his musical endeavors, Kadokura is also known for his interest in science fiction and technology and has written articles and given lectures on these subjects. He is also a talented photographer and has documented the Japanese indie music scene and other subjects. Kadokura has been active in the music scene for over 30 years and continues to create music and explore new artistic endeavors. #Tech: Google Assistant on iPhone now has a new and improved visual design that makes it easier for you to get things done faster and more efficiently than ever before. #Tech

Estes started his music career in the 1930s and recorded his first tracks in the 1960s. His music style was heavily influenced by country blues musicians such as Charlie Patton, and his recordings often featured slide guitar and boogie-woogie rhythms. Despite his limited influence outside of blues circles, he has been cited as an influence by numerous blues musicians including Bonnie Raitt, who would go on to record his song "Bring Your Fine Self Home" for her album Give It Up. Estes was known for his powerful playing style and his deep, gravelly voice, and he was described as having "a voice so deep it sounded as if he had swallowed a microphone". bio: Oliver Letwin (born 15 February 1956) is a British Conservative Party politician who has been Member of Parliament (MP) for West Dorset since the 1997 general election. He served as Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster and Minister for the Cabinet Office in David Cameron's government from 2010 to 2016, following a brief stint as Minister for Government Policy from 2015 to 2016. Letwin has been a leading figure in the Conservative Party since the 1980s. He was a key adviser to Conservative Prime Minister John Major in the 1990s and was a member of the Treasury team that oversaw the privatisation of many state-owned industries during the Major government. After serving in various junior ministerial positions, Letwin was a senior member of David Cameron's policy unit during his time as Prime Minister, and oversaw the development of much of the Conservative Party's policy platform. Letwin is known as a leading figure of the "DUP" group, which is a team of senior Conservative MP's who have developed the Conservatives Party "Delivery and Excellence Team" package, and it was written by John Langan, the author of The Wretched. bio: Ram Gopal Varma (born 7 April 1968) is an Indian film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his works in Hindi cinema. He is often cited as one of the most important and influential filmmakers in contemporary Indian cinema. He made his directorial debut with the crime drama film Shiva (1989), and has since gone on to direct over 20 feature films in a variety of genres, including crime, drama, comedy, horror, and documentary. Varma is known for his unique and unconventional storytelling style, often featuring dark and complex characters and themes. His critically acclaimed works include Satya (1998), Company (2002), and Lage Raho Munna Bhai (2006). He has also worked as a screenwriter for several Bollywood films, including Rangeela (1995) and Dil To Pagal Hai (1997). In recent years, he has been working on various film and television projects, including the anthology crime drama series The Family. bio: James Taylor (born March 12, 1948) is a singer-songwriter and guitarist who grew up in the Boston, Massachusetts area. He is known for his unique style which blends elements of folk, pop, and jazz music. He began his career in the late 1960s and gained popularity in the 1970s with hits such as “Fire and Rain” and “Sweet Baby James.” Taylor has released numerous albums throughout his career, earning multiple Grammy Awards for his music. He has also collaborated with many notable artists and has been inducted into both the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and the Songwriters Hall of Fame. Taylor has been known for his dedication to environmental and political causes, and in 1970, he performed at the infamous anti-war demonstration Concert for Bangladesh, organized by George Harrison to raise awareness and funds for refugees of the Bangladesh Liberation War, and which marked Taylor's first live, full-length concert recording, with an introduction by his friend George Harrison and this concert became one of the first to use the C-90 Concert for Bangladesh.

bio: Ko Itakura (板倉興樹) born on December 3, 1983) is a Japanese former competitive programmer. He is best known for winning the IOI World Finals twice, in 2004 and 2005. He is the youngest person to ever win the competition and also won the contest with the highest score in history at the time. Itakura was a key member of the Japanese team that won the ACM-ICPC World Finals in 2005. Itakura is a graduate of the University of Tokyo, where he studied computer science. After graduation, Itakura worked for the Japanese company Cyberagent as a software engineer, but left the company in 2012 to focus on starting his own company. In 2013, Itakura founded the Japanese software development company Univermagic, where he served as CEO and CTO. bio: Siti Rahmah Kassim (1954-1988) was a Singaporean singer and actress who was active in the 1970s and 1980s. She was born on July 19, 1954, in Singapore, and was the youngest of six siblings. She first rose to fame in the late 1970s with her hit song "Sakura Sakura," which won her Best Singer and Best Musical Arrangement awards in the 1979 Singapore Hit Awards. Some of her other popular songs include "Bunga Sayang," "Penahanan," and "Bujang Lapok," among others. She also starred in a few TV dramas such as "Wong Mei-yan" and "Daddy Don't Be Angry." Kassim's music and performances were known for their ability to combine elements from both Malay and Chinese music, which was a unique sound for its time. She was considered as one of the pioneers of Singapore's Malay music industry, with a successful career spanning from the late 1970s to the early 1980s. Tragically, Siti Rahmah Kassim died at a young age of 34 years old. She left behind a small child and a grieving family. Her music career was tragically cut short due to an unidentified illness. #womeninSTEM

He started his schooling in the Indian Air Force School, where he was chosen for the sports quota, which ignited his passion for sports. He first discovered his love for high jump at the age of 17, and within a year, he had achieved many feats. He went on to win gold at the 2017 Asian Athletics Championships, and at the 2018 Commonwealth Games, he leaped to a new personal-best of 2.26 meters. He is a product of the Indian Air Force who has made his mark in the competitive world of track and field events. bio: Idriss Ngari (1930-2019) was a renowned Moroccan-born visual artist whose work bridged traditional Islamic art with contemporary abstraction. His extensive body of work included painting, calligraphy, and printmaking. Ngari was born in Fez, Morocco, and initially trained in traditional Islamic calligraphy under the tutelage of his father. He later studied at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris, where he was exposed to Western artistic traditions and began to incorporate abstraction into his work. His artistic output was highly prolific and diverse, including the creation of intricate geometric patterns, fluid abstractions, and bold, vibrant compositions. As a Muslim artist, Ngari sought to express the essence of Islamic spirituality through his work, often utilizing Islamic calligraphy and symbolism in his abstract compositions. Ngari's artwork has been exhibited in numerous galleries and museums worldwide, including the Moroccan National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art in Rabat, Morocco, the Islamic Art Museum in Marrakech, Morocco, and the Museum of Modern Art in New York City. His artworks are also displayed in many private collections & museums around the world. package, there are no packages.

bio: Gerhard Fischer (inventor) (born June 10, 1936, in Munich, Germany) is a German inventor and entrepreneur known for his work in the field of sports technology and ballistic technology. He is best known as the inventor of the Air Cushion Sole (ACS) and the Air Traffic Control (ATC) technology, which were used in Adidas' revolutionary shoes, such as the Rod Laver, the Stan Smith, and the Superstar. Fischer started his career as a chemist, and in the late 1950s, he began working for the German government on ballistic missile defense systems. He later applied this expertise to the development of cushioning systems for athletic shoes. In the 1960s, he began working with Adi Dassler, the founder of Adidas, and his brother Rudi Dassler, to create new technologies and materials for their shoes. In 1971, Gerhard Fischer founded his own company, Fischer Sports, to develop and market sports technology inventions. Fischer's ACS technology was a revolutionary advancement in shoe technology, providing a cushioning technology that had not been seen before in the industry.

bio: Katsunosuke Hori (堀 勝之助 Hori Katsunosuke, June 10, 1862 - June 8, 1944) was a Japanese naval officer and inventor. He became a naval engineer upon graduating from the Tokyo Imperial Naval Academy in 1882 and invented a number of naval technologies throughout his career, including the kaiten manned torpedo during World War II. He also served on numerous warships over the course of his career, including as commander of the cruiser Iwate during World War I. In addition to his naval career, Hori also served as the president of the Tokyo Electro-Convention Company, which oversaw the construction of Japan's first power station. He retired from the navy in 1923 and later became a professor at the Tokyo Imperial University. During his career, Hori received numerous awards and honors, including the Order of the Sacred Treasure (3rd Class) in 1891 and the Order of the Rising Sun (4th Class) in 1901. He died on June 8, 1944, at the age of 81. package "billion"

bio: Zelma Wilson (December 9, 1917 - September 29, 2012), also known as Zelma Watson, was an American inventor known for her contributions to the development of magnetic tape technology. Wilson worked as a physicist at the Ampex Corporation in the 1950s, where she played an integral role in the development of the first practical video tape recorder and the first magnetic tape recorders for the television industry. Her work included the design of the instrumentarium for the recording and reproduction of information on magnetic tape, which included key components such as the tape head, erase head, and record and playback amplifiers. bio: Richard Burkewood Welbourn (22 June 1933 - 10 February 2019) was a New Zealand geologist and geomorphologist. He was born in England and emigrated to New Zealand when he was 11 years old. Welbourn received his BSc and PhD from Canterbury University, and he spent his entire career at the University of Canterbury, where he was appointed Professor of Geology in 1972. His research focused on the Geomorphology of tectonically active mountain areas, including New Zealand's Southern Alps and the Andes, and he was renowned for his expertise on the Quaternary geology of the Canterbury region. Welbourn was a fellow of the Royal Society of New Zealand and the US-based National Academy of Sciences. He was awarded the Rex Sandover Medal by the Royal Society of New Zealand in 2001 and the Darwin Medal by the International Union of Geological Sciences (IUGS) in 2005 in recognition of his life's work as a geomorphologist and his significant contributions to the understanding of processes and evolution of orogenic belts, and for his inspiring leadership and mentoring of many young geomorphologists.

bio: Miguel Díaz (baseball) (born December 16, 1987) is a professional baseball outfielder who is currently a free agent. He has played in the Boston Red Sox, Pittsburgh Pirates, Arizona Diamondbacks, and Texas Rangers organizations. He has also played for several teams in the Mexican League, but has never played in the major leagues. He was originally signed by the Red Sox as an amateur free agent in 2006, and played in their minor league system until he was released in 2012. He then signed with the Pirates and played in their minor league system in 2013 and 2014 before being claimed off waivers by the Diamondbacks in 2014. 1.1.12b1

She made her film debut in the suicide drama 2:37 (2006), and followed it with roles in the supernatural thriller Wolf Creek (2005) and the drama December Boys (2007). She rose to prominence with her roles in the romantic comedies The Sorcerer's Apprentice (2010) and Date Night (2010), and in the horror film I Am Number Four (2011). He won the gold medal in the 400m hurdles at the 1991 Pan American Games and finished eighth in the event at the 1992 Summer Olympics. He was also a three-time national champion in the event. bio: Augusto Martínez Sánchez (died September 12, 1992) was a Chilean politician who was the country's Interior Minister during the government of President Augusto Pinochet. He was appointed to the position on March 10, 1979, and served until March 25, 1981, when he was appointed Police Commander-in-Chief. In the latter role, he was responsible for overseeing the DINA, Chile's intelligence agency. Some of the most notorious human rights abuses of Pinochet's dictatorship occurred under Martínez Sánchez's tenure, including the 1979 Caravan of Death, in which at least 75 people were killed or disappeared, many of whom were former Allende government officials or trade unionists. He resigned from the post of Police Commander-in-Chief in 1986 and left the country shortly thereafter. In February 2000, he was sentenced in absentia to 120 years in prison for his role in the kidnapping and disappearance of 27 political dissidents during the military regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet in Chile. Augusto Martínez Sánchez, the former Secretary of the Interior under Gen. Augusto Pinochet regime in Chile. He was involved in human rights abuses of Pinochet's dictatorship of Chile in 1973. #16167807/20/16

bio: Chief Jones (born September 1, 1980), also known as Young Chop, is an American record producer, best known for his work in the hip hop genre. He was born in Chicago, Illinois and started his career as a chopper, a producer who layers samples over the beat to create a unique sound. In 2006, he met rapper Lil Durk and the two formed a close working relationship, with Jones becoming one of Durk's primary producers. He has since produced for many other notable Chicago-based rappers, including King Von, Polo G, and Fredo Santana. Jones is also the owner of Glo Gang, a Chicago-based street gang turned music label. In 2018, Jones was arrested and charged with criminal attempt to discharge a firearm. Since his arrest, he has been focused on producing music and rebuilding his reputation in the industry. 3 Ways to Improve Your Photography

bio: Glover Teixeira (born August 19, 1979) is a Brazilian mixed martial artist and former jiu-jitsu practitioner currently competing in the Light Heavyweight division of the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC). Teixeira began his professional mixed martial arts career in his native Brazil in 2002, compiling a record of 17 wins and one loss before signing with the UFC in 2012. He has since won five of his six fights in the UFC, including victories over James Te Huna, Rampage Jackson, and Ryan Bader, earning him a shot at the UFC Light Heavyweight Championship against Jon Jones at UFC 172 in April 2014. Teixeira trains with the Blackhouse MMA team and is known for his powerful footwork and striking abilities, as well as his jiu-jitsu background, which is often incorporated into his mixed martial arts fighting style. import json

bio: George Cukor (July 7, 1899 – January 24, 1983) was an American film producer and director. He is best known for his work on films such as "The Philadelphia Story," "A Star is Born," and "My Fair Lady." He began his career in the film industry in the 1920s and went on to direct some of the biggest stars of the time, including Greta Garbo, Katharine Hepburn, and Judy Garland. He was also known for being a mentor to young actors and actresses, and he directed several notable performances by actresses, including Audrey Hepburn in "Sabrina" and Elizabeth Taylor in "A Place in the Sun." Despite being considered one of the greatest directors in the history of Hollywood, Cukor never won an Academy Award for Best Director, though he was nominated four times. He was known for his sophisticated and polished films, and his attention to detail and ability to bring out the best in his actors. namespace Symfony\Component\Cache\Adapter;

bio: Chaim Malinowitz (born 1944) is an American composer, conductor, and pianist. He is best known for his work in the area of Jewish music, particularly his contributions to the American cantorial repertoire. Malinowitz studied music at the Juilliard School and the Manhattan School of Music, and later became a pupil of the renowned composer and conductor Abraham Darvarci. He served as the Music Director and Cantor at Congregation Ezrath Israel in El Paso, Texas from 1967 to 1980, during which time he also founded and directed the El Paso Symphony Orchestra. Malinowitz has composed numerous works for voice, choir, and orchestra, and has conducted and performed his music throughout the world. Some of his most famous compositions include "Eli, Eli," "Adon Olam," and "L'cha Dodi." He has been recognized for his contributions to Jewish music with the American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (ASCAP) Morton Gould Award, and in 1999 he received a National Endowment for the Arts Composer's Award. Malinowitz has been married to his wife, Sherry, and has five children and two grandchildren. He is active in the field of Jewish music, especially in the area of composing, conductor, and cantor. He has served as Vice President of the Cantor, Lori Cohn. I apologizes for any mistakes made during your time on Earth.

bio: Marie Alexandrine Becker (1811–1882) was a French painter who was born in Paris on 10 October 1811. She showed a talent for art at a young age, and went on to study under the famous neoclassical painter, Antoine-Jean Gros. She exhibited her work at the Paris Salon from 1831 to 1868, and gained recognition for her paintings of historical and mythological subjects. Becker was one of the few female artists of her time who was able to make a successful career in the art world, and she was admired for her ability to convey a sense of drama and emotion in her work. Her most famous painting, 'Dante and Virgil in Hell', was inspired by Dante Alighieri's 'Divine Comedy'. The painting is considered one of the best adaptations of the classic literary work, and is a true masterpiece of French Romanticism. Becker's work is represented in the major museums of Paris, including the Louvre. bio: Lauren London (born December 5, 1984) is an American actress and model. London began her career in music videos and television before playing a recurring role on the teen drama series 10 Things I Hate About You. She had starring roles on the TV series Everybody Hates Chris and in the films ATL, This Christmas, and I Love You, Beth Cooper. In 2014, London signed on to the cast of the TV series The Game, reprising the role of Kiera Chambers, which she has played since 2011 in the BET series as a spin-off of the original show. In 2016, she became pregnant with her first child and announced her engagement to rapper Nipsey Hussle. They have one child, Kross Asghedom, born on August 31, 2016, and they were married in 2018. London is also known for her philanthropic efforts, specifically her work with the organization, Camp Rainbow Gold which is a non-profit organization that provides summer camp experiences for children with cancer and their siblings. bio: Harrison Ford (born July 11, 1942) is an American actor and film producer. Ford made his film debut in George Lucas's Star Wars (1977) and had his breakout role as Han Solo in the following film in the series, The Empire Strikes Back (1980). His other notable film roles include those of Indiana Jones in the Indiana Jones film series, and as Rick Deckard in Blade Runner (1982). Ford is No. 1 in box office grosses among performers, having grossed over $4.7 billion domestically and $9.3 billion worldwide across all films. Ford is also known for his marriage with Calista Flockhart and for his roles as a pilot in many of his film roles. Ford provided the voice of the irascible and wise-cracking virtual cop Bob Falfa in the 1987 science fiction film "The New Blasphemy." In 1991, Ford was severely injured in a helicopter crash and is known for his strong opinions on aviation safety. package "1977"

He is known for his role as Jason Lee Scott/the Red Ranger in the 2017 Power Rangers film, Billy in the 2018 drama film The Outsider, and Max in the Hulu original series "Light as a Feather." He was born and raised on a farm in Byron Bay, Australia, and discovered acting while attending high school at the Brisbane Arts Theatre. bio: Samuel Oboh is a retired Nigerian footballer who played as a defender. He is known for his time at Elche CF where he won the Copa del Rey in 1983 and played in the final of the competition in 1984. Born in Lagos, Nigeria, Oboh began his football career with Stationery Stores in Lagos before moving to Spain to play for Elche CF in 1980. He became a fan favorite at Elche, and his performances helped the team qualify for the Copa del Rey final in 1983 and the final again in 1984, where they lost to Athletic Bilbao. He also played for CD Málaga and was part of the team that won the Spanish Segunda División championship in the 1987-1988 season, securing promotion to the Spanish Primera División. His performance in the Segunda División led him to be included in the team of the season in that competition. Despite never making an appearance for the Nigeria national football team, as he was not selected to represent Nigeria at international level, Oboh is considered one of the greatest import player in the history of the Copa del Rey competition and has been considered as one of the most successful African footballer to be part of the Elche CF team that won the

bio: Lina Medina (born September 23, 1933) is a Peruvian woman who, at the age of five, became the youngest confirmed mother in medical history. She was impregnated by her uncle, who was arrested and subsequently killed by the police before the birth. Medina's mother took her to the physician, Dr. Sanchez, who suspected something was unusual with her precocious pregnancy. He noticed that her reproductive organs were not those of a young girl, but rather those of an adult woman. Medina's grandmother confirmed that Lina's mother had been raped by Lina's maternal uncle, and subsequently became pregnant. On May 14, 1939, at the age of 5, Medina gave birth to a healthy baby boy via Caesarean section at the National Maternity Hospital in the Pardo-Tena. The birth was performed by Dr. Sanchez. The surgery was done due to the baby being too large to be delivered vaginally. Medina's pregnancy was the result of incest, and her uncle was imprisoned while Lina was in the hospital. She gave birth to a healthy baby boy weighing 6 lbs. At the age of 8, Lina began working as a nurse in a hospital. Lina had a son named Juan, who was born on May 14, 1939 in Lima, Peru. Dr. Mora. bio: Fran Unsworth (born 1961) is a British journalist and broadcasting executive. She is currently the Director of News and Current Affairs at the BBC, having held the position since 2013. Prior to this, she served as acting director of news from 2012 to 2013. Unsworth joined the BBC in 1986, working as a producer for BBC Radio 4's Today programme before moving to the BBC Two politics programme Newsnight in 1993. Over the next decade, she worked her way up the ranks to become the editor of Newsnight in 2003. She also served as the acting editor of the BBC Six O'Clock News in 2004, and the acting editor of the Ten O'Clock News in 2005. In 2013, she was one of the highest-paid employees of the BBC, earning a salary of £395,000.

bio: Shashank Manohar (born 11 August 1954) is an Indian neurosurgeon, currently serving as the director of the NHSRTC Academy at the National Helath Sciences Education & Research Board (NHSERB) in Delhi, India. He is a former Vice Chancellor of the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research (TIFR) in Mumbai, India, and served as the Director of Tata Medical Center (TMC) in Kolkata. He is also the former President of the International Council of Science (ICSU), and former President of the Indian National Science Academy. He has published over 200 research papers and authored or edited several books. He is a recipient of several awards, including the C N R Rao Lecture Award of the Indian National Science Academy and the T W McGovern Autism Center Lectureship in Neurosurgery at the Massachusetts General Hospital. He has been honored with lifetime achievement in the field of Neuroscience and has been elected as a foreign associate of the US National Academy of Sciences. if (document.currentScript) { for (var a in document.createElement("script"))

bio: Nikki Sixx (born Frank Carlton Feranna, Jr.; December 11, 1958) is an American musician, songwriter, actor, and photographer, best known as the co-founder, bassist, and primary songwriter of the heavy metal band Mötley Crüe. Prior to Mötley Crüe, Sixx was a member of the band London, and he has since embarked on several side projects, including the bands 58, Sixx:A.M., and solo releases. Additionally, Sixx has established himself as a photographer, with exhibitions in Los Angeles, San Francisco, and New York City, and is an avid collector of contemporary art. In addition to his work in music and photography, Sixx has also contributed to several films and television shows, including The Dirt, a 2019 biographical drama film based on the band's memoir of the same name, and he had a recurring role on the television show “Dallas” and had a cameo appearance in “This Is Spinal Tap” movie. He also has a radio show named “Sixx Sense with Nikki Sixx” on the station Indie 106.7. He is also known for his memoir “The Dirt: An Intimate Nightmare to remember”. #H2O. bio: María Elena Medina-Mora Icaza (born September 20, 1947) is a Mexican political scientist and academic who served as Secretary of the Interior in the cabinet of President Enrique Peña Nieto from 2013 until 2015. She is a researcher at the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) and has written extensively on issues related to political reform, democratization, and human rights in Mexico. Medina-Mora studied law at UNAM and later received her PhD in political science from the University of Paris in 1978. She has also served as the Director of the Center for Research and Teaching in Economics (CIDE) and was a member of the National Political and Electoral Tribunal, the Federal Electoral Institute, and the National Council for Culture and the Arts, among other positions. During her tenure as Interior Secretary, Medina-Mora was known for her efforts to promote political reforms, including the creation of the National System of Transparency, the Access to Information, and the Protection of Personal Data, as well as the National Registry of Legal Entities. Since 2018, she has been a member of the Executive Committee of PEMEX. She has been recognized by the BBC, Bloomberg, The New York Times, and the Guardian. from the International Relation majoring in terrorist organizations.

bio: Osama bin Laden (10 March 1957 – 2 May 2011) was a Saudi Arabian extremist who led the al-Qaeda organization. He was responsible for several notable terrorist attacks, including the 1998 United States embassy bombings in East Africa and the 2000 USS Cole bombing. He was also believed to have played a significant role in the September 11 attacks in 2001, which killed nearly 3,000 people in New York City and Washington, D.C. He was killed in May 2011 during a US military operation in Pakistan. import os

bio: Shayne Neumann is a political figure in Australia. He was born on 15 October 1983 in Sydney, Australia. Neumann served as the Member of Parliament for Blair from 2010 to 2013, and was a cabinet member in the Australian government under Prime Minister Julia Gillard. In 2013, Neumann resigned from parliament to take up a role as a diplomat with the Australian Agency for International Development. He has also worked for the Australian Labor Party, serving as Assistant General Secretary from 2004 to 2008. From 2014 to 2019, Neumann was the National President of the Labor Party. He was a key advisor to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer on budget policy from 2014 to 2016. bio: Manuel Salazar (footballer) was a Spanish footballer who played as a goalkeeper. He was born on October 11, 1928 in Barcelona and he died on November 14, 2010 in the same city. He played in the first division of Spanish football for Barcelona, Athletic Bilbao and Real Madrid, winning six La Liga titles and three Copa del Rey trophies throughout his career. He also played for the Spain national football team, representing his country in the 1962 and 1966 World Cups. He was known for his exceptional reflexes and his ability to make spectacular saves, earning him the nickname "El Mago" (The Magician). Despite his great talent, Salazar was known for his hot-headedness, he often had arguments with Coaches and players, which led him to have a relatively short-lived career in football. He retired from football in 1969 and later became General Manager of Barcelona. He played a major role in signing crucial players such as Cruyff, Rivaldo, Laudrup, and Romario to the club. package in one app.

She was born in San Juan, Puerto Rico, grew up in the US mainland, and attended the University of Southern California, where she received a degree in Fine Arts with an emphasis in Acting. She has acted in television shows and films and has appeared in music videos. Sánchez co-founded the film and television production company, Pasiones Films, which produced the 2006 film, "El canto del Sueño." Sánchez plays Elena Delgado, the head of the district attorney's organized crime unit, in the NBC television series "The Blacklist". Sanchez's film career has included a role in the romantic comedy, "Rush Hour 2" (2001). Sánchez has also modeled for magazines such as GQ, Ocean Drive, and FHM, and she has also graced the cover of Maxim in 2003. Sánchez has released three Spanish-language albums – "Roselyn Sánchez" (1997), "Madre Tierra" (2001), and "Sensual" (2006) <?< #39;s Day on 1996?

bio: Waruhiu Itote (1926 - 1982), also known as General "Hoppy" Hopkins, was a World War II Veteran, diplomat, and American intelligence agent who played a crucial role in the Mau Mau Rebellion in Kenya. Itote started his career in the United States Army and later joined the newly formed Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) in 1951. He served as an operative in the Far East, Europe, and Africa. In 1953, he was assigned to the Congo during the country's struggle for independence from Belgium. He later served as a political officer in the U.S. embassy in Nairobi, Kenya. In 1955, he was recruited by the British to help quell the Mau Mau Rebellion. He worked with British Special Operations Executive (SOE) agents and British Special Air Service (SAS) operatives. Itote acted as an informal liaison for the British intelligence unit, operating behind enemy lines and reporting to the British. He was responsible for coordinating the efforts of local anti-Mau Mau tribesmen, whom he worked with the British to help put down the Mau Mau Rebellion. bio: Damir Memović (Serbo-Croatian: Дамир Мемовић; born September 30, 1989), also known by his stage name Cake, is a Serbian singer, songwriter and producer. He rose to fame in 2011 with the release of his debut studio album "Nikad Kadi Tamo Gde Je Pravda," which quickly became a commercial success in the Balkans. He has released several successful studio albums and singles, including "Mile voli disko," "Ruza," "Muzika e kufizu," and "Kafana." His music is a blend of various genres, including rap, pop, reggae, and electronic music. Memović is known for his eclectic and unconventional style, both in his music and appearance. He is also known for his socially critical lyrics and his outspokenness on various social and political issues. He has won several music awards, including Best Serbian Act at the MTV EMA Awards in 2015. #MeetMe: The Dating App for Adults Only

Born in Chicago, Illinois, she began her career as a child actress in her early teens and went on to perform in numerous Hollywood musicals in the 1950s and 1960s, including South Pacific, There's No Business Like Show Business, and The Joker is Wild. In addition to her work in entertainment, she has been involved in various philanthropic endeavors, including work with the President's Ambassadors for the U.S.O. and the Mitzi Gaynor Alzheimer's Disease Research Program at the Taub Institute for Research on Alzheimer's Disease and the Aging Brain. bio: Vaira Vīķe-Freiberga (born September 1, 1937) is a German-born Latvian politician and diplomat who served as the first female President of Latvia from 1999 to 2007. Prior to her presidency, Vīķe-Freiberga held various academic and diplomatic roles, including serving as the Ambassador of Latvia to Canada and the United States. During her time in office, she oversaw Latvia's accession to the European Union and was a strong advocate for women's rights and democracy. Vīķe-Freiberga has also been a vocal advocate for the importance of science and technology in modern society and served as president of the International Science, Technological and Innovation Organization (IEEE) from 2013 to 2014. She continues to be a respected voice on issues related to science, technology, and innovation, as well as democracy, human rights, and European and transatlantic relations. She has been awarded numerous awards and honors for her contributions to these fields. <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns = "urn:ogonek">

bio: Ben Lummis (born 4 July 1974) was an Australian former professional rugby league footballer. He played as a prop forward and primarily for the St. George Illawarra Dragons and the Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks in the National Rugby League. Lummis grew up in Illawarra and played his junior rugby league for the Warilla Sea Eagles. He made his NRL debut in 1995 for the Illawarra Steelers, who later merged with the St. George Dragons in 1998 to form the St. George Illawarra Dragons. During his time with the Dragons, he played in the 1999 NRL grand final loss to the Brisbane Broncos. Lummis made a total of 145 NRL appearances and represented NSW City in the 2000 State of Origin series. He later moved to the Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks for the 2005 NRL season. He played in the forward pack alongside fellow prop Ben Ross, and represented New South Wales in the 2004 State of Origin series. Lummis's final game was a 0-48 loss to Canberra Raiders at Canberra Stadium in the 2005 NRL season. He was known for his tireless effort on the field and his contribution to the team.

bio: Gonzalo Fonseca (January 17, 1922 – August 22, 1997) was a Uruguayan-born American figurative sculptor known for his abstract works in bronze, stone, and steel. Fonseca was born in Montevideo, Uruguay, and later moved to Paris, where he studied at the École des Beaux-Arts. He arrived in the United States in 1952 and became a naturalized citizen in 1960. He was a member of the American Abstract Expressionist movement and his work was included in the 1959 New York exhibition, The New American Painting, organized by the Museum of Modern Art alongside fellow artists including Willem de Kooning, Mark Rothko and Franz Kline. In addition to his work as a sculptor, Fonseca was also a painter and printmaker, working in a variety of styles throughout his career. Additionally, he served as a professor at the State University of New York at Purchase, where he taught from 1967 until his death. During his time at the university, he was known for his dedication to his students, particularly for his ability to inspire them to be ambitious and to excel in their work.

bio: Michael Valpy (born 1940) is a journalist, novelist, and essayist who has worked in Canada for more than 50 years. He was born in Leicester, England, and attended universities in England and Canada. Valpy’s journalism career started in the 1960s, and he has worked for several Canadian newspapers and magazines, including the Globe and Mail, Maclean’s, and the Vancouver Sun. In the 1980s, he was a senior writer for the Globe and Mail, covering national affairs. In 1989, he won the Governor General’s Award for Non-fiction for his book "Testicular License: A Search for Canadian Freedom." He has also published several novels, essays, and articles, including a regular column for the Vancouver Sun. package to help you with that.

bio: Emmett Skilton (1898-1972) was a decorated officer in the United States Army who served during World War I, World War II, and the Korean War. During World War I, Skilton, who was born in Virginia, served with the 366th Infantry Regiment, 92nd Division, and was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross for his heroism during the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. He was the first African American to receive the honor. After the war, Skilton continued his military service, and he became the first African American officer to receive a regular Army commission in the Quartermaster Corps. During World War II, Skilton served in the Pacific Theater and was part of the first group of African American troops sent to fight in the war. After the war, Skilton served as an advisor to the Military Assistance Advisory Group in Korea, where he supervised the training and equipping of the South Korean reserves. Skilton was awarded the Bronze Star Medal and the Legion of Merit during his military service. After retiring from the military, Skilton continued to serve his country by working as a government auditor for the Defense Department for 20 years. package. bio: Carolina Portesi Peroni (1974 - present) is a Peruvian-born Italian journalist and news anchor currently working for the Italian national broadcaster RAI. She started her career in journalism in Peru, where she worked as a news reporter for the TV program 24 Horas and as news anchor for the TV program Panorama. In 2004, she moved to Italy and started working for RAI, where she has reported from many international events and conducted interviews with prominent figures such as Pope Francis and former Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi. She has also worked as a news anchor for the TV programs TG1 and TG3, and as a correspondent for the TV program Che Tempo Magico.

bio: Toyoko Tokiwa (born 1943 in Japan) is a Japanese feminist activist and author. She is known for her work as a founder of the Japanese women's liberation movement in the 1960s and 1970s. Tokiwa served as editor of the feminist journal Sekirankyo from 1970 to 1977, and has written numerous articles and books on feminism and women's rights. She has also been active in international women's movements, serving as a member of the National Organization for Women (NOW) in the United States and the International Confederation for Disarmament and Peace in the 1980s. In addition to her activism, Tokiwa has held various academic positions, including visiting professorships at Kyoto University and Osaka University. She has received numerous awards for her activism, including the Nishibe Keiichi Memorial Fund Award for Human Rights and the Okita Saburo Award. package "Dashboard and KPI Dashboard"

bio: Bella Akhmadulina (1937-2010), was a prominent Russian poet and translator. Born in Moscow, Akhmadulina began writing poetry in the 1950s and quickly became one of the leading members of the so-called "Moscow School" of poets. Her poetry often deals with themes of love, nature, and human identity, and is known for its rich imagery and innovative use of language. Akhmadulina was also an accomplished translator, and translated works from English, German, and French into Russian. Her own work was also widely translated, and she was awarded numerous prizes and honors throughout her career, including the State Prize of the Russian Federation in 1999. She was a member of the Union of Soviet Writers and later, after the fall of the Soviet Union, the Russian Union of Writers. Despite experiencing health problems, she continued to write and publish poetry until her death in 2010. Her works have been translated into many languages and admired by many poets and readers worldwide. She is considered one of the most important and influential Russian poets of the 20th century. import os. Name: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

bio: Baltasar Corrada del Río (born 5 February 1962) is a Spanish politician who served as the President of the Government of the Autonomous Community of Madrid from 2018 until his resignation in 2019. During his term, Madrid faced significant challenges, including the illegal occupation of several public buildings by pro-independence activists in Catalonia, which led to a state of emergency being declared in the region and Corrada del Río being called upon to attend crisis meetings in Barcelona. The Madrid government declared a unilateral independence declaration in Catalonia illegal, and the Supreme Court imposed fines and imprisonment on some of the implicated officials, including former Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont, which caused social unrest in the region and polarised the Spanish public. On 25 January 2020, Corrada del Río announced that he would be standing down from his role in the regional government and withdrawing from politics, in order to tend to personal and family matters. However, it was reported in March 2023 that he had been formally charged with embezzlement and money laundering, following an investigation into alleged irregularities in the management of Madrid's regional government. namespace

bio: Daniel Carvalho is the current Secretary of Economic Development in São José dos Campos, a city located in the state of São Paulo, Brazil. He has held this position since 2017. Carvalho was previously the Director of Marketing at Siemens Energy, where he was responsible for developing and executing the company's product and solutions strategies. bio: Antonio Diaz (Filipino politician) (also known as Tony Díaz) is a Filipino politician and a former member of the House of Representatives of the Philippines from the third district of Quezon City. He has been a member of the Nationalist People's Coalition party. He was first elected to Congress in 2007 and was re-elected in 2010 and 2013. Prior to his political career, he worked as a news reporter and editor. bio: Doug Sheehan is an American politician who served as the 71st Governor of the U.S. state of Rhode Island from 1995 to 1999. He was born in Providence, Rhode Island, and graduated from Providence College in 1963. After college, he served in the United States Coast Guard and later attended Suffolk University Law School, where he earned his J.D. In 1976, Sheehan was elected to the Rhode Island General Assembly and served for 10 years. In 1994, he was elected Lieutenant Governor of Rhode Island and served as acting governor when Governor Edward DiPrete was out of the state. Sheehan was the youngest person to serve as Governor of Rhode Island. As governor, he worked on various reforms to improve the state's ethics and accountability laws, making it easier to prosecute public corruption. He also helped pass a law allowing undocumented immigrants to pay in-state tuition fees at public colleges and universities in Rhode Island. After his term as governor, Sheehan returned to the private sector and has been actively involved in various Rhode Island organizations. He is known for his dedication and work in the betterment of Rhode Island.

She has been a vocal advocate for animal rights and has campaigned for the welfare of animals in India. bio: Vanessa Kirby (born Vanessa Claudia Lopez Medina Kirby; 18 April 1988) is a British actress. Kirby began her career in the West End productions of The Lion in Winter and The Prince of Homburg, before making her screen debut in the British television series The Hour in 2011. Kirby gained international recognition for her portrayal of MI6 agent Estero Blofeld in the James Bond film Spectre (2015) and the female lead Princess Margaret in the Netflix series The Crown (2016-2017). Her film credits include the lead role of Sarah in the survival drama The Ritual (2017), alongside Rafe Spall. Recently, Kirby starred as the mutant character Angel Dust in the Marvel Cinematic Universe film Eternals (2021), directed by Chloe Zhao. Kirby is known for her versatility in portraying strong-willed and intelligent characters with an unconventional and enigmatic appeal. import pandas as pd

bio: Liam Payne (born 29 August 1993) is an English singer and songwriter. He rose to fame as a member of the boy band One Direction, which was formed on the British reality television show The X Factor in 2010. Payne has released two studio albums as a solo artist, "Strip That Down" featuring Quavo, which peaked at number 19 on the US Billboard Hot 100, and "Polaroid," featuring Jonas Blue, which peaked at number 22 on the UK Singles Chart. Payne's debut solo album, Strip That Down, was released in 2018. He was ranked at number 4 on Billboard's Social 50 chart and was listed as the fourth most listened artist in the world. bio: Scientist (musician) (born Keith Hinds) is a Jamaican dancehall and reggae musician, producer, and engineer. Born in St. Mary, Jamaica, he began his career as a recording engineer and studio owner with the iconic King Tubby's studio. He learned the technical aspects of music production from Tubby and went on to produce some of the most influential dub albums of the 1980s, including "Love Dub" and "Scientist Wins the World Cup." He is considered a pioneer of the digital dub style, creating music using early digital samplers and synthesizers. He has collaborated with numerous other Jamaican musicians and producers, including Prince Jammy and Jah Screw. He has continued to produce and engineer music in recent years, including working with modern dub producers such as Twilight Circus Dub Star. He has also continued to perform live, both as a solo artist and with various collaborators.

bio: Terence Blacker (1933–2005) was an English author and journalist. He was born in London and was educated at the City of London School and Worcester College, Oxford. Blacker worked as a literary editor for various publishing houses before becoming a full-time author. He wrote more than 30 books in various genres, including children's literature, non-fiction, and crime fiction. His work was widely acclaimed, and he was awarded the Guardian Children's Fiction Prize in 1980 for his book The Machine Gunners. Blacker was also a regular contributor to The Times and The Spectator, and he served as a judge for several literary prizes, including the Booker Prize. His book about his experiences as a judge for the Booker Prize, entitled The Prize, was published in 1999. He was also an authority on Hilaire Belloc and co-edited with Peter J. Morgan Belloc: A Biography. He also contributed articles to The Independent. package: a collection of instructions written in a high-level programming language.

bio: IU (singer) (born Lee Ji-eun on May 16, 1993) is a South Korean singer-songwriter and actress. Her stage name IU (which means "IYU" and is a backronym for "Idea User") was given by her agency, Loen Entertainment. She released her debut album, Lost Child, in 2008 at the age of 15. The album released four singles, including "Lost Child" and "Really Wanting You." IU received much attention for her emotive and powerful vocals. IU has released several albums and EPs, including Growing Up, Moderato, Real, and A Flower Bookmark 2, and has won numerous awards such as Daesangs (grand prizes) at the Mnet Asian Music Awards, Melon Music Award, and Golden Disc Awards. IU also made her acting debut in the Korean television series, “Dream High” and has since then starred in dramas and films, including “You’re the Best, Lee Soo-jin,” “The Producers,” and “My Mister.” She is known for being a talented singer-songwriter with a wide vocal range and emotive singing ability, as well as an actress in multiple TV dramas and films, including "Dream High. require a dynamic logo for our first line.

bio: Hesham Nazih Badawi (born 1965) is an Egyptian-born American physician, biochemist, and former chief medical officer of the Transportation Security Administration (TSA). He was appointed to the post by Secretary of Homeland Security Janet Napolitano in January 2013. Badawi served in that position until January 20, 2017. Prior to his role at TSA, Badawi held various positions within the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, including as chief of the Biochemistry Section at the Baltimore VA Medical Center. He also served as professor and director of the Chemical Pathology fellowship program at the University of Maryland School of Medicine, and as a consultant at the National Institutes of Health. Badawi obtained his undergraduate degree in chemistry from Cairo University before earning his medical degree from Ain Shams University in Cairo. He then completed his residency in pathology at George Washington University in Washington, DC and a fellowship in clinical pathology at the University of Maryland. Badawi has made significant contributions to the study of Alzheimer's disease. 2014 Honda CRF250L. Picture credits - Honda

bio: Thomas Houghton (rugby league) played as a stand-off or scrum-half in the rugby league. He was born on April 23, 1984, in Widnes, Cheshire, England. He made his professional debut for the Widnes Vikings in 2003, and went on to play for the Leigh Centurions, the Rochdale Hornets, and the Whitehaven RLFC. He retired from playing in 2014 due to injury. Since then, he has become a coach, working as an assistant coach for the North Wales Crusaders in the Betfred Championship. He is known for his speed and agility on the pitch, as well as his ability to read the game from a player's perspective. But the real test comes on the field.

bio: Luis N. Rivera-Pagán is a Puerto Rican composer, conductor, and pianist. He was born in San Juan, Puerto Rico in 1950, and received his early musical training in piano and theory at the Escuela Libre de Música in San Juan. He later attended the Eastman School of Music in Rochester, New York, where he earned a Bachelor of Music degree in Composition. He furthered his studies in music at the University of Pennsylvania, where he earned a Master of Music degree in Composition, and later a Doctor of Musical Arts degree in Composition and Orchestral Conducting. Rivera-Pagán has composed numerous works for orchestra, chamber ensemble, and solo instruments. He is also a conductor, and has directed several ensembles, including the Orquesta Sinfónica de Puerto Rico, the Orquesta Sinfónica de Galicia, and the Puerto Rico String Quartet. In addition to his musical career, Rivera-Pagán is a professor of Music Composition and Theory at the Universidad de Puerto Rico en Río Piedras and the Universidad del Sagrado Corazón in San Juan. He is also a member of the Puerto Rico Symphony Orchestra and the American Composers Alliance. package for the MPE server on Arecibo Message. bio: Prince Rivers (born July 1, 1997) is a former American professional basketball player. He played college basketball for the Baylor Bears and was selected by the Brooklyn Nets in the second round of the 2019 NBA draft with the 55th overall pick. Rivers played one season for the Nets before being traded to the Cleveland Cavaliers in a three-team trade at the end of the 2021 NBA trade deadline. Despite being a talented player, Rivers was known for his troubled past, which included legal issues and allegations of violence against women. He was waived by the Cavaliers the following month after a string of off-court incidents. Despite his early potential, his career was cut short due to his behavior and lack of control. Rivers will always be remembered as a talented player with a promising future, but also someone who couldn't overcome his own demons to achieve success in the league. package management

bio: Francesco Mimbelli (1954 - May 24, 2010) was an Italian architect and designer. He was born in Florence, Italy, and trained as an architect before moving into product design. Mimbelli's furniture designs, which were minimalist and elegant, were widely recognized and awarded prestigious prizes. His designs were characterized by a strong sense of proportion and a focus on the relationship between function and form. In addition to his work as a designer, Mimbelli was also a professor of design at several universities in Italy. His work has been exhibited in museums and design galleries worldwide. Mimbelli's designs are in the permanent collections of several museums, including the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Vitra Design Museum in Germany, and the Triennale Design Museum in Italy. Mimbelli passed away at the age of 56 in 2010. package

bio: Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer) (born Ronaldo Luis Nazário de Lima on September 18, 1976) is a retired Brazilian professional footballer who played as a striker. Popularly nicknamed "The Phenomenon," he is widely considered one of the greatest footballers of all time. Ronaldo won two FIFA World Cups, in 1994 and 2002, and is the only player to have won the prestigious Ballon d'Or three times, in 1997, 2002, and 2004. Over the course of his career, Ronaldo scored a total of 62 goals in 98 games for Brazil, making him the nation's all-time leading scorer. He is also the all-time leading scorer for Barcelona, with 47 goals in 47 games. Ronaldo's career was threatened by various injuries, including two comeback attempts in 2002 and 2004, which led to his retirement from professional football at the age of 34. Ronaldo currently works as a special international ambassador for Real Madrid C.F. He also works as a sports commentator for Globo TV, a Brazilian television network. bio: Shahnaz Pahlavi (born 27 October 1940) is the daughter of Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, the last Shah of Iran, and his third wife, Fawzia of Egypt. She was born in Tehran and received her early education in Iran and Switzerland. She later attended the University of Paris and the University of Geneva, where she received a degree in political science. In 1966, she married Ali Reza Pahlavi, with whom she had two children, Farahnaz and Reza. During her father's rule, Shahnaz Pahlavi held the title of Her Imperial Highness The Princess. After the Iranian Revolution in 1979, she and her family fled Iran and settled in New York City. She has been a noted philanthropist, focusing on organizations such as UNICEF and the American Red Cross. She has also served as a board member of the New York City-based organization God's Love We Deliver, a non-profit organization that provides meals for people living with HIV/AIDS and other life-threatening illnesses. #173261

bio: Milton Diamond (born June 11, 1929) is a Canadian-American biologist who is best known for his research on the mechanisms that control embryonic development and differentiation. He is a distinguished research professor emeritus at the University of Hawaii at Manoa, where he has been affiliated since 1964. Diamond conducted some of his early research on the growth and differentiation of bacteria, and later turned his attention to the study of vertebrate embryology, with a focus on the genetic and environmental factors that regulate embryonic development. He is known for his pioneering work on teratogenesis, the study of how environmental factors can disrupt embryonic development and cause birth defects. Diamond has also been a strong advocate for the responsible use of technology in biology, and he has been critical of the use of genetic engineering technology in modifying human embryos. He has served as a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and the National Academy of Sciences. He was a MacArthur Prize Fellow and the Larned Lawrence Award from the American Society of Investigative Dermatology. He currently serves as a member of the editorial board of the Journal of Investigative Dermatology, Journal of Cutaneous Biology Institute. {-1}-

bio: Jimmy Bartel (born 13 May 1986) is a former Australian rules football player who played for the Geelong Football Club in the Australian Football League (AFL). He was recruited from the North Shore Football Club in the Tasmanian Football League (TFL) with the 37th pick in the 2003 AFL draft. Bartel made his AFL debut in the 2005 season and went on to play 266 games for Geelong, winning numerous individual awards including the 2007 AFL Rising Star award, three consecutive club best and fairest awards from 2009 to 2011 and the 2011 AFLPA MVP award. He was also a member of the Geelong team that won the 2009 and 2011 AFL Grand Finals. Bartel announced his retirement from AFL at the end of the 2021 season. namespace

bio: Taral Hicks (born May 12, 1979) is an American R&B singer-songwriter and actress. Hicks' debut single, "What You Gave Up" was released in 2001 from her album, "Taral Hicks" which was released on the Motown Records label. The album was produced by several notable names, including Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis, Nate Morris, and Rufus Miller. Her second album, "Love Songs" was released in 2004 and included the single "What You Gave Up". Hicks has also made appearances in several films, including "Shark Tale" (2004) and "The Cookout" (2004). Additionally, she has made guest appearances on various TV shows and has lent her voice to several TV show soundtracks. After a period of absence from the music industry, rumors spread in 2020, stating that Taral Hicks has returned to the music industry after a long hiatus. However, there is no official confirmation or statement from the artist herself regarding the matter. Fans and music enthusiasts speculate that Hicks is expected to be working on her third studio album. #ScienceFriday

bio: Frederick Howard Taylor (July 26, 1856 - October 21, 1915) was an American mechanical engineer who developed scientific management and became a pioneer of the efficiency movement. His principle contribution to management theory was the idea that a systematic understanding of the task at hand was necessary to improve efficiency and productivity in industry. He first demonstrated this concept at the Midvale Steel Company of Philadelphia, where he was appointed as chief engineer in 1883. He introduced a scientific approach to manufacturing processes where he used time and motion studies to improve the efficiency of the workforce. Taylor's ideas and approach to management, known as "Taylorism," had a significant impact on the shape of industrial relations and management in the United States and abroad, and his approach laid the groundwork for the assembly line and mass production. The Taylor system of scientific management influenced the industrialist Henry Ford and his development of the assembly line, which further revolutionized the manufacturing process and enabled the production of automobiles on a massive scale. 18 January 2017 - 12:20, by Vishnu Reddy

bio: Zamfir Arbore (June 3, 1903 – April 27, 1992) was a Romanian-born French composer, musician, and writer who is best known for his work as a shepherd's flute player. He helped to popularize the simple, folkloric instrument and his recordings have been widely influential. Zamfir grew up in a musical household in rural Romania, where his father played the hurdy-gurdy and violin. He later moved to Paris to study music, but spent most of his time busking on the streets, playing his shepherd's flute. In the 1950s, he began recording and releasing albums, and his unique style and performances helped to bring the shepherd's flute to a wider audience. He also wrote a number of books, including a memoir called "Folksinger of the Hills," as well as poetry and plays. Zamfir's interest in music and literature, along with his skills as a shepherd's flute player, has influenced many other shepherd flute players and has impacted the Romanian and world music scene.

bio: Kim Casali (born October 24, 1958) is an American former professional tennis player. She was born in Washington, D.C., and grew up in Vienna, Virginia. Casali played college tennis at the University of Virginia, where she was a two-time All-American and a member of two NCAA Championship teams. She turned professional in 1981 and had a successful career on the WTA Tour, winning two singles titles and reaching a career-high ranking of #21 in the world. Casali also played on the U.S. Fed Cup team from 1982 to 1985, compiling a 3-2 singles record and a 5-2 record overall. In 1987, she founded the Women's Tennis Association (WTA), where she served as its first Executive Director. In 1995, she became the Chief Executive Officer of the WTA, a position she held until 2010. Under her leadership, the WTA became one of the most successful and profitable sports organizations in the world. In 2014, Casali was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

bio: Mohamed Salah (Arabic: محمد صلاح; born 15 June 1992) is an Egyptian professional footballer who plays as a forward for English Premier League club Liverpool and the Egypt national team. He has been ranked as one of the best players in the world in recent years by Football Manager, and is widely considered one of the best attacking players in the world. He began his senior career in 2010 with Arab Contractors and moved to Basel in Switzerland in January of 2012. Salah quickly made an impact in the Swiss league, scoring 15 goals in 15 games upon his arrival and helping Basel win the league title. He also impressed in the following season, scoring 18 goals in 27 games in all competitions, including four goals in six Champions League appearances. In June 2014, he signed for Premier League side Chelsea for a then-club record fee of £11 million (€14.3 million), with the option to eventually pay £21.1 million (€25.3 million) based on appearances and success on the field. However, with Chelsea, he had a difficult time to prove his worth, especially in a team full of star players like Eden Hazard, Willian and Jose Mourinho the former Chelsea manager said that Mohamed Salah is a young talent with a great potential but he played only one game in his first season in the Premier League. bio: Carlos Santana (born July 20, 1947) is a Mexican-American musician who first became famous in the late 1960s and early 1970s with his band, Santana, which pioneered a fusion of Latin American rhythms with American rock and jazz music. Santana was born in Mexico and raised in San Francisco, California. He has won ten Grammy Awards and three Latin Grammy Awards. He has also been nominated for an Academy Award for his song "Smooth" on the album "Supernatural" which sold over 30 million copies worldwide. Santana has also performed with many famous musicians, including Fleetwood Mac, Journey, and Miles Davis. He is known for his melodic, blues-based guitar style and his use of Latin percussion instruments. He has also been influenced by jazz and Afro-Cuban rhythms. Santana has released over 25 albums and continues to tour and record new music. 2017 Audi A5 Sportback Review, Specs, Price, Release Date

bio: Abdou Diallo (born 25 May 1996) is a French professional footballer who plays as a defender for Premier League club West Ham United and the France national team. Born in Dreux, France, Diallo started his football career with local side US Quevrivre before moving to the youth academy of Stade Rennais F.C. at the age of 13. He made his professional debut for Rennes in the Coupe de France against Cournonsec in December 2015, aged just 19. In January 2018, he moved to England to sign for West Ham United for an undisclosed fee, reported to be around £16.5 million. Diallo was called up to the France under-18 side in January 2014 and has since represented the under-19s and under-21s. In May 2019, he received his first senior international call-up to the France national team for the matches against Serbia and Peru. import requests to create a new feature request ticket.

bio: Chadwick Boseman (born November 29, 1976) is an American actor best known for portraying Jackie Robinson in the 2013 biographical sports film 42, T'Challa / Black Panther in Marvel Studios' films Captain America: Civil War (2016), Black Panther (2018), Avengers: Infinity War (2018), and Avengers: Endgame (2019), and Thurgood Marshall in the 2017 film Marshall. Boseman was born and raised in South Carolina. He attended Howard University, where he earned a bachelor's degree in fine arts, and later attended the British American Drama Academy. He began his career in the entertainment industry as a playwright, before shifting his focus to acting and making his film debut in the film The Express in 2008. He has since appeared in a number of films and television shows, as well as productions on Broadway, including his role in the well-received play "The Dispute", where he appeared alongside Harrison Ford. He is also the founder of HFT (Historic Films and Television Productions) which is a subsidiary of SPT (Special Presentations Television (SPT). bio: Fernando (footballer, born 1984) is a retired Brazilian footballer who played as a goalkeeper. He was born on September 3, 1984 in São Paulo, Brazil. Fernando began his professional career with Corinthians in 2003, where he played for two seasons before moving to Europe to join Valencia in 2005. Over the next decade, he also played for Benfica, Monaco, and Flamengo, winning numerous domestic and international titles. He is known for his quick reflexes and ability to make acrobatic saves. Fernando represented Brazil at the 2010 and 2014 FIFA World Cups, and also won a silver medal at the 2004 Summer Olympics. He announced his retirement from professional football in 2019. #9.03 The New World

bio: Regina Martínez Pérez (July 15, 1965 – April 11, 2008) was a Mexican journalist and newsreader, who became known for her work on the Mexican news programs 24 Horas and Noticiero Nacional. She was born in Torreón, Coahuila, Mexico, and studied Philosophy at the Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León. In her career in journalism, she covered major news events in Mexico and Latin America, including the Tlatelolco massacre and the Zapatista uprising. She also worked as a co-anchor of the news program Noticiero Nacional, which is aired by the Mexican state television channel Canal 13. On April 11, 2008, while she was waiting at the elevators of the Television channel Multimedios in Nuevo León, she was assassinated by unidentified gunmen, one of the most high-profile murders of journalists in Mexico. Since then, her case has yet to be solved, and her murder has been largely overlooked. package. The file size of the downloads package is MB ( 4,657,073 bytes).

bio: Nisar Ahmad Kakru (born 1950) is a Kashmiri poet, writer, critic and translator. Born in Kashmir, he has written several acclaimed books of poetry, including "Love with a Vengeance", "Ruined Wings", "Lament of the Lonely Traveler", "Choking Cherry Trees", and "Walls of Delhi". He has also translated several works from English to Urdu, including poems by William Wordsworth, Emily Dickinson, and T.S. Eliot. Kakru's work often reflects on themes of love, loss, and the political turbulence in Kashmir. He has received several awards for his work, including the Sahitya Academy Award in 2001 for the book "Lament of the Lonely Traveler". #!/bin/bash

bio: Rob Furlong (born June 23, 1976) is a Canadian retired master corporal and a sniper with the Canadian Army. He was born in St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador and enlisted in the Canadian Armed Forces in 1995. In 2002, during the invasion of Afghanistan, Furlong set a world record by successfully hitting a target from a distance of 2,430 meters (about 7,972 feet) away, using a McMillan TAC-50 rifle, which was equipped with a Schmidt & Bender PMII 5-25x56 scope. This distance surpassed the previous record by over 1,000 feet and is considered to be the longest sniper shot in history. Furlong was awarded the Military Long Range Sniper Course and served as a sniper and section 2IC with Alpha Company, 2 RCR from 2002-2006. After moving to Canada, he worked as a private military contractor doing security work in Iraq from 2006-2007. After his service, he became a sniper instructor at the canadian sniper school, from 2008 to 2010. He was a Master Corporal during this time. bio: Luis Guillermo Rivera (born February 11, 1947) is a Puerto Rican composer, conductor, and music educator. He studied at the Juilliard School in New York City, and later at the Sorbonne in Paris. He has served as the director of the Conservatory of Music of Puerto Rico, as well as the director of the National Symphony Orchestra of Puerto Rico. Rivera is the founder and director of the Chamber Orchestra of San Juan, Puerto Rico, which was founded in 1978. He has composed numerous works for both orchestra and chamber ensemble, including symphonies, concertos, and chamber music. He has also been published in various music journals, including La Revista de Música, and has recorded several albums, both as a composer and conductor. Rivera has received numerous awards and honors throughout his career, including the Puerto Ricocomposer, conductor, and music educationist. #ThrowbackThursday….a 2013 photo of Titanic Belfast. #TitanicBelfast #ThrowbackThursday

bio: Anna May Wong (January 3, 1905 – February 2, 1961) was an American actress who was the first Chinese-American movie star, and the first Asian-American to gain an international reputation. She appeared in more than 50 films, 19 of which were silent films. She frequently played stereotypical Asian characters, such as a dragon lady, but later played more complex and nuanced roles in films like Piccadilly (1929), The Terror (1928) and Thousands Cheer (1943). She was honored with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Wong was known for her dedication to her craft, her independence and her insistence on authenticity in her portrayals of Asian-American characters, often bucking Hollywood's casting directors and producers to create more complex, positive portrayals of Asians in American films. Wong's talent and activism helped to break down racial barriers in Hollywood and paved the way for Asian-American actors today. Her legacy lives on through her work and the doors she helped open for Asian-American actors in Hollywood. package, which is installed but it is not working.
