bio: Lanny Flaherty (born 1950) is a game designer and author, best known for his work on the role-playing game Deadlands. He has worked as a freelance writer and designer, creating material for various game systems over the years, and has been especially associated with the game company Pinnacle Entertainment Group. Flaherty wrote or contributed to several popular Deadlands supplements, such as "The Great Rail Wars," "Legends of the Old West," and "Wetworks," and also wrote or co-wrote several other game lines for Pinnacle, such as "The Great War: 1914-1918," "Savage Worlds Adventure Edition," and "Eastern Front." bio: Jean Daullé (26 July 1923 – 26 September 2006) was a French physician, pharmacist and chemist, most famous for his research on alcohol addiction. He was born in Périgueux, France and studied medicine and pharmacy in Bordeaux. He began his career as a medical officer in the French army in Algeria before he returned to Bordeaux to work as a pharmacist. He then moved to Paris to work as a researcher at the Pitié Salpêtrière Hospital, where he worked with Pierre Bichet on researching the effects of alcohol on the body. In 1962, he founded the Addiction Research Institute, where he conducted research on alcoholism and addiction and developed a program of psychodynamic therapy for addicts, known as "the Daullé method." He published several books, including "The Alcohol Problem" in 1973, in which he discussed his experiences and research on addiction. Jean Daullé made significant contributions to the field of addiction research and developed a successful program to help addicts overcome their addiction. He was a well-respected and experienced physician, pharmacist and chemist. He is known for his research on alcohol addiction. He is responsible for developing a program of psychodynamic therapy for addicts in France.

bio: Daniel Charles (August 14, 1946 – February 15, 2012) was an American mathematician who focused on the arithmetic of Diophantine equations. He received his undergraduate degree from Cornell University in 1968 and earned his Ph.D. from Princeton University in 1974 under the supervision of John Tate. Charles joined the faculty of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1974, where he remained until his death. During his career, Charles made significant contributions to the fields of number theory, arithmetic geometry, and related areas. He was known for his works on Diophantine approximation, elliptic curves and Diophantine equations, and the arithmetic of abelian varieties. Charles received many honors and awards for his research, including a Guggenheim Fellowship, a MacArthur Fellowship, and a Fellowship of the American Mathematical Society. He retired from MIT in 2011.

bio: Gilberto Silva (born April 7, 1976) is a Brazilian former professional footballer who played as a defensive midfielder. He is widely considered one of the greatest Brazilian players of his generation. He played for five clubs throughout his career, including Paris Saint-Germain, Arsenal, and Panathinaikos. Silva was known for his exceptional ball-winning ability and his capacity to dictate play in midfield. He was a key player for Arsenal during their "invincible" season in 2003-2004, where they went the entire campaign unbeaten and won the Premier League title. Silva also won two La Liga titles with Barcelona, as well as a number of domestic and international trophies with other clubs. He was capped 103 times for Brazil, scoring three goals, and represented his country in two FIFA World Cups and three Copa America tournaments. During his time with Arsenal, Silva helped the team win the 2003-2004 Premier League title, where he was an integral player that year, playing in 38 of the team's 38 Premier League games that year and also starting 7 of his team's 13 Champions League games that year. Silva has retired from professional football in 2014. 1. The best time to post on social media platforms

bio: Jessica Barboza (born May 5, 1984) is a volleyball player from Brazil. She was a member of Brazil's national team from 2002-2012, where she earned a silver medal in the 2008 Beijing Olympics, a gold medal in the 2011 Women's South American Volleyball Championship, and a gold medal in the 2011 FIVB World Grand Prix. She also won a bronze medal in the 2004 Athens Olympics, and was the third-highest scorer at the 2006 FIVB Women's World Championship. She was named the best spiker at the 2006 FIVB Women's World Championship. She played professionally in Brazil, Turkey, and Italy, and was named the best outside hitter in the Turkish League in 2014. She played for Fenerbahçe Acıbadem in 2013-2014 season and Eczacıbaşı VitrA Istanbul in the 2014-2015 season. She is widely regarded as one of the best volleyball players of all time. 1001 SolarMovies.

bio: Vincenzo Tusa (born 16 July 1931) is a Maltese politician and lawyer who served as the third President of Malta from 1989 to 1994. Tusa graduated as a lawyer from the University of Malta in 1955 and later became a member of the Maltese Parliament, serving in various parliamentary committees and as speaker of the House. He was also a member of the Executive Council of the Maltese Government, serving as a minister without portfolio, and later as Minister of Health, Education and the Family. Tusa was also a member of the Council of Europe and served as President of the Committee of Ministries of the Council of Europe from 1988 to 1989. In addition to his political career, Tusa also contributed to the development of the Maltese legal system, particularly in the areas of constitutional and administrative law. Tusa authored several books, including "Irreversibility in Administrative Law" and "Malta: The Constitution." He also published articles on various legal topics, including "La protezione dell'ambiente (Protection of the Environment)" and "La responsabilità dell'amministratore di sistemi." #ScienceFiction from a distant planet.

bio: Lewis Nkosi (December 28, 1936 - November 18, 2010) was a South African writer, translator, and literary critic. He was a leading figure in the anti-apartheid movement, and was instrumental in establishing the Congress of South African Writers in the 1970s. Nkosi was born in Johannesburg, and grew up in a township township. He received his education at the University of Witwatersrand where he studied drama before moving to London in 1961, where he became involved in the anti-apartheid movement. He later returned to South Africa to continue his activism, and continued to write, publish and translate for the rest of his life. Nkosi published several works, including the novel Moffie, which depicts the struggles of a young man coming to terms with his homosexuality during apartheid-era South Africa. He also published memoirs in which he reflects on his childhood, family, education, South African literary scene, the anti-apartheid movement, and the development of South African Literature. He was awarded the Sunday Times Fiction Prize for his novel Moffie. import java.util.Scanner. You can create a scanner in java and use it to read input from user

He was also a member of the Parliament of Iran from 2000 to 2004, representing the city of Ahvaz in Khuzestan Province. Prior to his political career, Zolani worked as an engineer and held several high-level positions in the private and public sectors in Iran. He is known for his expertise in the oil and gas industry and has been involved in several major projects in Iran. Zolani is a graduate of Sharif University of Technology, where he earned a degree in mechanical engineering. He also holds a master's degree in petroleum engineering from the University of Tehran. bio: Carlos Alfonso is an Argentine-American computer scientist. He is a professor of computer science at Johns Hopkins University, where he has been on the faculty since 1992. His research interests include artificial intelligence, cognitive robotics, and symbolic and statistical computation. He is known for his work on machine learning and robotics, and has published numerous papers and articles in these areas. Alfonso received his Ph.D. in computer science from the University of California, Los Angeles in 1990. Prior to joining the faculty at Johns Hopkins, he worked as a research scientist at the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, where he contributed to the development of the first prototype of the CYC knowledge base. Alfonso is a fellow of the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence and a member of the Association for Computing Machinery and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers.

bio: Botak Chin (September 12, 1923 – February 12, 1945) was a Chinese-born American soldier who posthumously received the United States' highest military award, the Medal of Honor, for his actions during World War II. Chin was drafted into the U.S. Army in 1943 and was sent to fight in the European Theater of Operations. In February 1945, during the Battle of the Bulge, Chin's unit was attacked by a German tank. Despite being wounded, Chin engaged the tank in hand-to-hand combat and managed to knock out the tank. However, the tank was later revealed to have been a decoy and Chin was killed by the Germans. He was posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor for his actions, becoming one of only six Chinese Americans to receive this honor in the history of the U.S. military. The Medal of Honor is the highest military decoration within the United States Armed Forces. It is awarded to members of the United States Armed Forces who distinguish themselves by their outstanding bravery and/or outstanding heroism against an enemy of the United States. Botak Chin received the award for his heroic actions in the Battle of the Bulge on January 12, 1945. #0906-2198

bio: Roberto Clemente (August 18, 1934 – December 31, 1972) was a Puerto Rican professional baseball player who played 18 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Pittsburgh Pirates. He was an outfielder and was known for his gifted defense and blazing speed on the base paths. He was a twelve-time All-Star and one of the greatest players of all time. He was the first Latin American and Caribbean player to reach 3,000 hits, and he also hit over.300 in twelve different seasons. Clemente was also known for his humanitarian work, particularly in Puerto Rico and other Caribbean countries. He died on January 1, 1973, when a shipment of supplies and food he had arranged to be sent to earthquake victims in Nicaragua fell into the ocean after the pilot of the plane, who was not authorized to fly under the dark skies and in bad weather, ignored Clemente's orders to turn back, crashed the plane into the ocean. The wreckage of the plane was found on the beach on New Year's Day. In October 1973, the Pittsburgh Pirates honored Clemente by creating the Roberto Clemente Day, an annual event in which they celebrate the humanitarian work. The club also created the Roberto Clemente Award, given annually to a Pirate's player who exemplifies Clemente's humanity, sportsmanship and the humanitarian contributions to society. #3

bio: Robert Louis Stevenson (13 November 1850 – 3 December 1894) was a Scottish novelist, poet, and travel writer, with a strong interest in horror and the supernatural. Born in Edinburgh, Stevenson was the son of a civil engineer. He studied law at Edinburgh University, but was interested in literature and spent a great deal of time reading. In 1880, he met Fanny Osbourne, an American woman who was in France with her children. The two began a long-distance relationship, and were eventually married in 1880. They lived in Edinburgh for a time, but eventually moved to the Samoa Islands, where Stevenson became a citizen of the island of Apia. His works include "Treasure Island," "Kidnapped," and "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde." #DearNadiyaHussain: How do we cope when tragedy strikes? bio: José Sánchez del Río (September 28, 1913 – February 10, 1928) was a Mexican Catholic boy who was born in the state of Guanajuato. He was a student and altar server at the village school and church. When the Mexican Revolution broke out, the region became a battleground. José was captured by soldiers in 1927 and accused of being a spy for the opposing faction. Despite being tortured, José maintained his innocence and refused to renounce his faith. He was shot and beheaded on February 10, 1928, in the village of Sahuayo, in the state of Michoacán, at the age of 14. He was beatified by Pope John Paul II on November 20, 1998, and was canonized by Pope Francis on October 16, 2016. He is the youngest non-martyred saint in the Catholic Church, and his feast day is celebrated on February 10. #OTD in 1968 - 24-year-old Charles Manson and 10 other members of his cult are arrested for the brutal murder of Sharon Tate and four other people.

bio: Toru Muranishi (村西 徹 Muranishi Tōru, born September 2, 1972) is a former Japanese football player. He has played for several clubs, including Kashiwa Reysol, Gamba Osaka, and Vissel Kobe. He also played for the Japanese national team, making his debut in 1997 against South Korea. He played in several international tournaments, including the 1998 FIFA World Cup, the 2000 AFC Asian Cup, and the 2004 AFC Asian Cup. He announced his retirement from professional football in 2010. After retiring, he became a football commentator, working for J Sports. He also appeared in various television shows, such as "Muranishi's One-Man-Show." package

bio: Florencia Bertotti (born September 10, 1975) is an Argentine actress who has appeared in various movies and television series. She is perhaps best known for her role as "Romina Guerrero" in the series "Los protegidos." Her career began in the early 2000s, with minor roles in films such as "Corazones de sombra " (Shadow Hearts) in 2003 and "El sueño de los sueños " (The Dream of Dreams) in 2005. Her first major role was in the soap opera "Rosario de Sonora " in 2004, for which she won an ACE Award for Best Supporting Actress. She later played "María José 'Majo' Pérez" in the television series "El refugio " in 2006 and "Paula Márquez" in "Se dice amor " in 2007. She starred as "Romina Guerrero" in the series "Los protegidos" from 2012 to 2013. Bertotti has won several awards, including the ACE Award for Best Actress for her work in "Los protegidos." bio: Chris Cheney (born 21 January 1975) is an Australian singer-songwriter and guitarist, best known as the frontman of the rock band The Living End. He formed the band in 1996 with childhood friends Scott Owen and Travis Dempsey while he was still a high school student in Melbourne. The band released their debut album, "Modern Artillery," in 1997 and gained a wide following in Australia with their energetic live performances and blend of punk and rockabilly influences. Cheney continued to be a guiding force in The Living End's music, co-writing many of their hit songs such as "All the Same," "Under the Sun," and "Prisoner of Society." The band released six albums and toured extensively, both in Australia and overseas. Cheney also collaborated with other Australian musicians in various projects. In 2016, Cheney released his debut solo album, "Kingsize Soundtrack," which showcased his songwriting and musical skills and demonstrated his versatility as a musician. The album received positive reviews and marked Cheney's debut as a solo artist. Cheney continues to perform with The Living End and work on his solo projects. **NOTE: I have moved my portfolio of work to a new portfolio/project management system. Some of the work we did 6-7 years ago. #

bio: Eric Hacker (born September 20, 1987) is a former American professional baseball player. He played in the pitcher position for the Pittsburgh Pirates of Major League Baseball (MLB) in parts of the 2011 and 2012 seasons. He played college baseball at the University of San Francisco, where he was named the West Coast Conference Player of the Year in 2008. Hacker was drafted by the Pirates in the 13th round of the 2009 MLB Draft. He made his MLB debut on May 25, 2011, against the Houston Astros, pitching 2 scoreless innings and striking out Johnny Cueto. In July 2012, Hacker had Tommy John surgery to repair a torn ulnar collateral ligament in his elbow. Hacker officially announced his retirement from professional baseball in 2020. package the code

bio: Hibo Wardere (born 1978) is a Somali-British advocate and writer, known for her work campaigning for women's and children's rights. Wardere was born in Mogadishu, Somalia, and at the age of nine she was forced to marry a man in her extended family. When she was 19, she moved to the United Kingdom to live with her sister and her husband, who helped her to escape from her abusive marriage. In 2003, she founded the organization "We Can Win," which aims to educate and empower young women and girls in Somalia and the UK.In 2016, Wardere published her memoir, "What Happened to Hibo?" which gives an account of her experiences and aims to raise awareness about child marriage, domestic violence, and the importance of educating girls and women. Wardere was appointed Member of the Order of the British Empire (MBE) in the 2021 New Year Honours for services to Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) Advocacy.

bio: Egon Krenz (born 19 March 1937) is a former East German politician who served as the General Secretary of the Socialist Unity Party of Germany (SED) and as President of the Council of State of the German Democratic Republic from October 1989 to November 1989, during the final weeks of the country's existence. He was born in the town of Lindenau, near Schwerin, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, then part of Nazi Germany, and joined the SED in 1955. After the SED seized power in October 1949, Krenz worked his way up through the party's ranks, serving as First Secretary of the SED District Committee in Schwerin from 1981 to 1984, and as a member of the SED Central Committee from 1984. He became the longest-serving leader of East Germany, in power from May 18, 1989 until November 7, 1989. On November 7, 1989, Krenz announced that travel restrictions between East and West Germany be lifted and that citizens of the GDR can travel freely in and out of the country. The announcement was one of the first changes in the country's history. However, the GDR was dissolved on October 3, 1990.

bio: Heinrich Harrer (1 July 1912 – 2006) was an Austrian mountain climber, sportman, writer, and explorer. Harrer was born in Ehrenhausen, Carinthia, Austria-Hungary (now Austria). He gained fame in the 1930s and 1940s for being one of the first people to climb the North Face of the Eiger in Switzerland. In 1938, he became the first person to summit the west face of the Pamir Mountain in what is now Tajikistan. During World War II, Harrer served in the German Wehrmacht, but was imprisoned in 1943 in British India after the Battle of Stalingrad. He managed to escape from his prison camp in 1944 and wandered the Tibetan plateau for the next few years, where he met the 14th Dalai Lama, who had fled from Tibet after a uprising and was living in India. The meeting of the two men would have a profound effect on both their lives and would leave an indelible mark on the lives of countless others. After spending time with the Dalai Lama, Harrer wrote Seven Years in Tibet, which is a book about his experiences during his captivity in the Indian military custody at Sikkim. Harrer left the region, who was made in His autobiography

bio: Don Featherstone (artist) (January 22, 1936 – July 8, 2018) was an American artist best known for his work in advertising. He was the creator of the iconic "Inexplicable Hacker" mascot for National Software Testing Labs, which debuted in 1984 and became one of the most recognizable images of computers in the late 20th century. He also worked for many years at the advertising agency of Cliff Freeman and Partners, where his work included creating the "Upson Downs" campaign for National Lampoon magazine and the "Boy Meets Boy" campaign for Out magazine. His designs for the New England Confectionery Company's "Necco" brand were so popular and well-known that they were put on display at the Smithsonian Institution's Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York City in 2010. using a VPN to unblock geo-restricted content.

bio: Mike Trivisonno (born May 28, 1947 in Cleveland, Ohio) is an American radio talk show host. He is currently employed by iHeartMedia's WTAM in Cleveland, where his program runs from 5:00 AM to 9:00 AM, EST, as of September 2017. He has worked in broadcasting for over 45 years, starting his career in 1972 at WWVA in Wheeling, West Virginia. Over the years, Trivisonno has hosted a number of popular television programs, including his own PBS show, "Let's Talk with Mike Trivisonno." He is known for his conservative and libertarian political views, as well as his distinctive Italian-American heritage. He has won numerous awards for his work, including the prestigious Associated Press's Ohio Broadcaster of the Year award in 2000. Trivisonno has used his platform to raise millions of dollars for various charities and causes throughout his career. He is known for his unique wit, distinctive voice, and quick-witted interviewing style. Throughout his career, Trivisonno has gained a reputation as a conservative, libertarian, and a talk show host. Known for his distinct voice and interview style, he has raised millions of dollars through his career and has a reputation for his conservative package for Windows 10.

bio: Daniel Dubois (boxer) (born 21 September 1997) is an English professional boxer who has held the British heavyweight title since 2018. He is managed by Frank Warren and trained by Martin Bowes. He is known for his aggressive fighting style and powerful punches, particularly his right hand. Dubois made his professional debut in October 2017, winning by knockout in the first round. He has remained undefeated since, with notable victories over Gary Sullivan and Tom Little. His most notable fights took place on the undercard of the Joshua vs. Parker fight in March 2018, and the Joshua vs. Povetkin fight in September 2018 where he defeated Tom Little. In November 2019, he defeated Richard Lartey to win the vacant WBC International Heavyweight Title. In January 2020, he successfully defended his title by defeating Razvan Cojanu by unanimous decision. Dubois had a stellar 2020 in which he successfully defended his WBC International Heavyweight Title by defeating Joe Joyce by split decision. In his last fight in 2021, he defeated Kyotaro Fujimoto in the 8th round. package for the most powerful ARES EMS ARES is an advanced research aircraft. bio: Tiffany Haddish (born December 3, 1979) is an American comedian, actress, and writer. She received critical acclaim for her performance as a drug-addicted hooker in the 2017 film "Girls Trip," and has since become one of the most sought-after comedians in the entertainment industry. Haddish was born in South Los Angeles, California and grew up in a foster care system. She later lived in Atlanta, Georgia, where she began her stand-up comedy career. In addition to her film and television appearances, Haddish has also made numerous stand-up comedy specials, including "Tiffany Haddish: She Ready! From the Hood to Hollywood" on Showtime, which won a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Variety Special in 2018. She has also been named as one of the most influential people in the world by TIME magazine, and has been nominated for a Golden Globe and an Academy Award for her performance in "Girls Trip". Haddish continues to be active in the entertainment industry and has signed on to appear in several upcoming films and television shows, including "The Tempest" and "The Oath." bio: Craig Morton (born September 23, 1944) is a former American football quarterback who played in the National Football League (NFL) for the Dallas Cowboys, Denver Broncos, and New York Giants. He played college football at Cal Poly, where he won the NAIA National Championship in 1965. He was drafted by the Cowboys in the third round of the 1967 NFL Draft, and played for the team from 1967 to 1968 and again from 1979 to 1981. During his first stint with the Cowboys, he won Super Bowl VI over the Miami Dolphins. After leaving the Cowboys, he played for the Denver Broncos and New York Giants before retiring in 1984. Morton was the first quarterback to pass for more than 3,000 yards in a single season, doing so for the Cowboys in 1977. He was inducted into the Cal Poly Athletics Hall of Fame in 1994. He was inducted into the Cowboys' Ring of Honor in 2013. He is currently a member of the NFL Broadcasting Network as a commentator, analyst, and game analyst. bio: Virginia Valli (November 20, 1899 – February 13, 1968) was an American film actress and singer. Born as Margaret Frieda Radnitz in Davenport, Iowa, she was known as "The Girl Who Came from Nowhere" due to her sudden rise to fame. She began her career in theatre and vaudeville before moving to Hollywood to work in films. She appeared in over 40 movies between 1919 and 1945. Valli was also a successful nightclub performer and recorded several songs in the 1920s. She married actor Lon Chaney in 1926, but the marriage was dissolved two years later. Valli died in Los Angeles in 1968 at the age of 68. #365DaysofInnovation

bio: Kerser is an Australian hip hop artist, born as Christopher John Kerser on December 13, 1990, in Melbourne, Victoria. He rose to prominence in the Australian hip hop scene in the early 2010s, with his unique style influenced by American hip hop legends like Tupac Shakur and The Notorious B.I.G. Kerser's music is centered around themes of hardship, his rough upbringing, and ambition to escape a life of poverty. He is known for his powerful lyrics that tell his life story in a relatable way to his listeners. Kerser's debut EP, The Nurture Versus Nature, was released in 2011 and received critical acclaim from hip hop fans and music critics alike. He quickly gained a loyal following and solidified his status as one of Australia's most promising hip hop artists. Kerser has since released several successful albums and continues to tour and perform in Australia and New Zealand, with his music crossing over to a wide range of audiences. His rise to fame has made him one of the most influential and popular hip hop artists in Australia. importlib

bio: Malcolm Hedding (born 1949) is a British theologian and Christian leader. He served as the International Director of the Association of Vineyard Churches from 1989 to 2007. During his tenure, he oversaw the expansion of the Vineyard movement from a small movement in California to a global network of over 2,500 churches in over 100 countries. He has written several books on Christian spirituality and leadership, including "Rediscovering the Kingdom" and "The Tabernacle in Our Midst". Hedding is currently the Executive Chairman of the Global Vision Forum, a missionary sending agency that is part of the Evangelical Movement of Wales. He is also the editor of the Global Vision Forum News, which connects people who are passionate about the nations and building the Kingdom of God on earth. In addition to his work with the Vineyard and Global Vision Forum, Hedding has also been involved with several other organizations, including the Lausanne Committee for World Evangelization and the World Evangelical Alliance. function?

bio: Takeo Miki (1907-1988) was a Japanese statesman and politician who served as Prime Minister of Japan from 1974 to 1976. He joined the Diet of Japan in 1936 and served in various cabinet positions throughout his career, including Minister of International Trade and Industry and Minister of Finance. Miki is known for his efforts to reform Japan's economy and for his advocacy of a more assertive Japanese foreign policy. He also played a key role in negotiating the Okinawa Reversion Agreement, which established the return of Okinawa to Japan by the United States. Miki was a member of the Liberal Democratic Party and served in the House of Representatives until his death in 1988. He is considered one of the most important political figures in postwar Japan, and his political legacy continues to influence Japanese politics to this day. namespace Symfony;

bio: Lua Blanco, born on October 13, 1883, in the small town of Maracay, Aragua State, Venezuela, was a remarkable educator, teacher, journalist, and political leader. She began her teaching career in Maracay, where she taught history and geography at the Escuela Urbana de Niñas, and later moved to Caracas to continue her work. During her tenure as a teacher, she was known for her dedication to education and her commitment to promoting women's rights. Blanco also had a successful career as a journalist and was the founder of several newspapers, including La Razón and La Estrella. She was also involved in politics, serving in the National Congress of Venezuela from 1921 to 1922, making her the first woman to hold a legislative position in Venezuela. Blanco was known for her firmness, dedication, and principles. She was ahead of her time, and her contributions to education, journalism and politics have been crucial in the formation of an independent and impartial press, as well as the promotion of the role of women in Venezuelan political life.

bio: Kyu Sakamoto (1941-2015) was a Japanese singer and songwriter. He was born Eitaro Ozawa in Amakusa, Kumamoto, Japan. Sakamoto was best known for his debut single "Ue o Muite Arukō" (known as "Sukiyaki" in the United States), which became an international hit in 1963, reaching number eleventh on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. The song's success helped launch the 1960s boom in Japanese pop music, known as the Group Sounds era. Sakamoto continued to record and perform throughout the 1960s and 1970s. He was also known for his use of a then-unique style of singing, which emphasized breath control and vocal clarity. Sakamoto's songs were often characterized by simple, catchy melodies and lyrics that aim to convey the joyful and positive aspects of life. Over his career, Sakamoto released hundreds of recordings and sold millions of records. Sakamoto's hit, "Ue o Muite Arukō" is one of the most influential and beloved songs in Japanese music history, often cited as the song that brought Japanese contemporary music to the world's attention. require assistance? He previously worked for the Liverpool Echo and national newspapers such as The Independent and The Guardian. King has been reporting on Liverpool Football Club for over a decade and is considered one of the leading voices on the club, covering all major games and events. He is also an expert on the English Premier League and international football, with a particular focus on player transfers and rumors. King's work has earned him a strong following among football fans and pundits, who appreciate his thorough reporting and analysis. In addition to his journalism, he is a regular contributor to TV and radio programs related to football, offering his insights and expertise on the sport. bio: Quintus Sosius Senecio (c. 105–43 BC) was a Roman senator and politician who served as a close advisor to Julius Caesar during his rise to power, and later as his legate and governor. He was a prominent supporter of Caesar during the Civil War, and was one of the dictator's most trusted confidants. Senecio became one of the wealthiest men in Rome, and was a member of the Roman senate and held the position of censor. He was also appointed as consul in 54 BC and was granted the honorary title of "Father of the Fatherland" in recognition of his service to Rome. Senecio was known for his skillful oratory and his extensive knowledge of law and governance, which he used to great effect in his political career. He is perhaps best known for his role in persuading the Roman Senate to grant Caesar his long-sought after province of Gaul, which would later become known as the Roman Province of Gaul. package "FastAPI-React"

bio: Jagan is an Indian politician and the leader of the All India Anna Dravida Kazhagam (AIADMK) party. He has been a Member of the Parliament for the Sriperumpudur constituency in Tamil Nadu since 2014 and has served as the Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu from 2011 to 2014. Prior to entering politics, Jagan worked as a software engineer and later became involved in social and political activism. Jagan is the nephew of former Tamil Nadu Chief Minister J. Jayalalithaa, and has been a key figure in the AIADMK since his aunt's death in 2016. He is known for his controversial statements and has been involved in a number of political controversies, including allegations of corruption and nepotism. Despite this, Jagan has been able to maintain his position as the leader of the AIADMK and has expressed a commitment to social justice and welfare in Tamil Nadu. He is known for his charismatic and populist style of politics, and has been referred to as the "Young Tiger of Tamilnadu". package

She also became the first female referee to appear in the FA Cup, when she officiated a match between Cambridge United and Leeds United in 2012. Massey-Ellis also participated in a scientific study in which researchers from the University of Lincoln examined her decision-making processes while officiating a football match. bio: Alexandre Guilmant (12 March 1831 – 23 March 1911) was a French organist, composer, and teacher. He is regarded as one of the most important French organists and composers of his time. Guilmant was born in Saint-Félicien, a suburb of Beauvais, France, and showed an early talent for music. He received his training at the Lycée Louis-le-Grand in Paris, where he studied under Adam and Benoist. In 1854, he became organist at the church of Saint-Séverin in Paris, and, in 1871, he was appointed to the prestigious post of organist at the Saint-Sernin Basilica in Toulouse. While at Saint-Sernin, Guilmant performed and taught extensively, and he made many important contributions to organ music and organ construction. He was particularly known for his organ technique known as "Guilmant's method." Guilmant also composed a considerable amount of organ music, and his compositions are highly regarded. He wrote many important works for the organ, including his famous "Pièces de fantaisie," "Allegro ma non troppo" and "Prélude, fugue et final". In addition to his work as an organist and composer, Guilmant also served as a professor at the Paris Conservatory. He died in 1911. bio: António de Oliveira Salazar (28 April 1889 – 27 July 1970) was a Portuguese economist and politician who served as the Prime Minister of Portugal from 1932 to 1968, and as the President of the Council of Ministers from 1935 to 1968. He studied at the University of Coimbra, where he earned a Doctorate in Political and Economic Sciences. He was appointed to the faculty at the University of Coimbra, where he became a full professor of economics. He became the Prime Minister of Portugal in 1932, and his regime became known for its authoritarian and nationalist policies. He implemented import substitution industrialization, which made Portugal self-sufficient, and created a fascist-leaning dictatorship known as the Estado Novo (New State). The regime was known for its corporatist economic policies, Estado Novo promoted a new corporatist economic model, where the state regulates and manages industry, trade unions, and employer associations, providing a unique system of interventionism, where the state is the key actor in the economy. He was known as the "Doutor" (Doctor) Salazar to his colleagues and subordinates. He also led an isolationist foreign policy, and stayed neutral during the Second World War. #Susan B. Anthony?

bio: Jidenna Theodore Mobisson (born May 23, 1985), known professionally as Jidenna, is an American singer, songwriter, and record producer. He was born in Wisconsin and raised in Nigeria. He attended Milton Academy and the Boston Latin School before attending Wake Forest University in North Carolina, where he studied graphic design. While in college, Jidenna formed a rap duo called Edibles with his friend Alex Mishael. They performed together as Edibles and released an album in 2009 called "Black Opera." Jidenna later made his solo debut in 2015 with the hit single "Classic Man," which was remixed in 2016 with rapper Kendrick Lamar. In 2017, Jidenna signed with Janelle Monae's Wondaland Arts Society label and released his debut album "The Chief" that year. The album featured guest appearances from Quavo, Janelle Monae, and others. library in the database.

bio: Rakhi Sawant (born Neeru Sawant on 25 November 1978) is an Indian film and television actress, dancer, and television talk show host. She appears mainly in Bollywood films and has been part of several television shows. Sawant was born in Mumbai, India, and began her career in modeling and dance. She became popular for her item numbers in several Hindi films and television shows. Sawant has also appeared in several reality shows, including Bigg Boss, Nach Baliye, and Jhalak Dikhhla Jaa. She has been involved in controversies due to her outspoken opinions and behavior, including a public lip-sync battle with fellow Bollywood actress Urvashi Rautela, and her comments on the 2008 Mumbai attacks. Sawant has also been involved in other controversies, including a legal case filed against her for her remarks about the Indian Army. Recently, in 2021, Rakhi Sawant was arrested for allegedly running a prostitution racket in Mumbai. She is known for her bold and outspoken nature and has often stirred controversy with her statements and actions. She has been involved in several legal disputes, including suing her for defamation due to her controversial statements and actions. bio: Song Kang (born July 31, 1956) is a South Korean film director, screenwriter, and producer. He is known for his innovative and artistic approach to filmmaking, which often explores themes of identity, memory, and history. Kang began his career as a film critic before transitioning into filmmaking. His feature film debut was the 1991 film "Green Fish", which won the Palme d'Or for Best First Film at the 1991 Cannes Film Festival. He followed this with films such as "The Day a Pig Fell Into the Well" (1998) and "Memories of Murder" (2003). His film "The Age of Shadow" (2016) is a crime thriller that takes place during the Japanese occupation of Korea in the 1920s. In 2019, Kang's film "Parasite" won the Academy Award for Best Picture, making him the first Korean filmmaker to win an Oscar. He is considered one of the most important South Korean filmmakers of his generation. package, including one of its subsidiaries,

bio: Bridget Moynahan (born April 28, 1971) is an American actress and model. She was born and raised in Longmeadow, Massachusetts, and graduated from the Longmeadow High School in 1989. Moynahan began her career as a model in the early 1990s and later began acting on television and in films. She made her film debut in the low-budget movie "Coyote Ugly" in 2000 and achieved widespread recognition for her role as Dr. Erin Harkins in the television drama "Six Feet Under" from 2000 to 2005. Her other notable film roles include "The Sum of All Fears" (2002), "The Recruit" (2003), "I, Robot" (2004), "Lord of War" (2005), and "Battle: Los Angeles" (2011). She also had a supporting role in the CBS crime drama "Blue Bloods" as Erin Reagan, the daughter of the New York City Police Commissioner. In 2010, she gave birth to her first child, a son named John. She also appeared in the movie "Battle: Los Angeles". #LSSC #KRKR #CricketFever

bio: Rennie Fritchie, Baroness Fritchie (1931 - 2017) was a British Liberal Party politician and life peer. She was educated at the North London Collegiate School and the London School of Economics. During the 1960s, she worked as a researcher for the Institute for Fiscal Studies and the National Association of Labour Women. She was elected as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for the London constituency in 1979 and served in that capacity until the UK's withdrawal from the European Union in 2020. She was created a life peer as Baroness Fritchie, of Brondesbury in the London Borough of Camden, in 1999, and served in the House of Lords until 2020. 🏆 Congratulate @john on Winning the $1M Cash Tournament! 💰

bio: Ji Sung (born on December 27, 1977) is a South Korean actor and model. He made his acting debut in 1999 with a minor role in the television series "School 4" and gained recognition for his role as a prosecutor in the hit drama "All In" in 2003. He has since starred in numerous dramas, including "Save the Last Dance for Me" (2004), "New Heart" (2007), "Pendaebaek" (2010), "Haeundae Lovers" (2012), and "Defendant" (2017). Outside of acting, Ji Sung also worked as a model, appearing in various advertisements and photo shoots. bio: Annika Sörenstam (born October 9, 1970) is a Swedish retired professional golfer. She was born in Bro, Sweden. She started her professional career in 1992 and retired in 2008, after having won 72 international tournaments, including 9 Major Championships. She was inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame in 2003, and is widely regarded as one of the greatest female golfers of all time. Sörenstam's success came despite being just 5 feet 11 inches (180 cm) tall, which was considered relatively short for a professional golfer. She also had a unique sideline in business, having co-founded the A Annika brand of clothing and accessories in 2003, and later started a successful wine label, Annika's Blend, producing a variety of wines with a particular focus on the 2010 vintage. Sörenstam has also worked as a broadcaster and golf analyst for the Golf Channel. In addition to her professional golfing career, Sörenstam is widely regarded as one of the greatest female golfers of all time. import C

bio: Robert Smith, Baron Smith of Kelvin (born 10 September 1950) is a British Labour Party politician who has been a Member of Parliament since 1987. He served as Minister of State in the UK Department for Transport from 2009 to 2010, Minister of State for Universities and Science from 2010 to 2012 and Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster and Minister for the Cabinet Office from 2012 to 2015. He was created a life peer as Baron Smith of Kelvin on 7 August 2015. Before he became an MP, Smith worked as a researcher and in local government in Glasgow. He has also held several positions within the Labour Party, including spokesman for transport, industry and employment, and education. He has been a member of the Science and Technology Select Committee and the Committee on Climate Change. package, and it can be configured at installation time.

bio: Paul O'Neill (racing driver) (born 20 October 1955 in Wimbledon, London) is a British former racing driver. He is best known for winning the European Formula Two Championship in 1983, and for driving in 83 Grands Prix for the Tyrrell and Arrows teams between 1985 and 1989. O'Neill started his career in karting, before progressing to single-seaters and winning the British Formula Ford 1600 championship in 1980. From there, he moved to British Formula Three, before winning the European Formula Two Championship in 1983, and the Macau Grand Prix. After an unsuccessful attempt to qualify for the 1984 Formula One season, O'Neill moved to the IndyCar series in 1986, where he drove for both Dick Simon Racing and Patrick Racing. In 1988, O'Neill joined the newly-formed Arrows Formula One team, which had been set up by his manager, and two-time World Champion, John Watson, and driver/owner of the team, and he stayed with the team for two seasons, before being dropped in favor of Eddie Irvine, and then replaced by Alain Prost. package of the year. bio: Eliza Dushku (born December 30, 1980) is an American actress, model, and voice actress, who was born in Watertown, Massachusetts. She is known for his work on the TV series "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" and "Angel" where she plays Faith Lehane. She is also known for her role as Lizeveta in the movie "The New Guy" and as Savannah Monreaux in the series "Tru Calling". bio: Beenie Man, born Anthony Moses Davis on August 22, 1973, is a Jamaican reggae dancehall musician. He adopted the stage name "Beenie Man," a play on the Chinese term "beanery boy," which was used to refer to Jamaican immigrants working in the United States in the early 20th century. He gained mainstream popularity in the late 1990s and early 2000s with hits such as "Girls Dem Sugar," "Over the Sea," and "Feel It Boy," the last of which won him his first Grammy Award for Best Reggae Album in 2002. bio: Kim Burrell (born August 26, 1972) is an American gospel singer, author and television personality. She was born in Houston, Texas, and began singing in church at the age of three. Burrell released her debut album, "I Am," in 1992 and has since recorded and released several albums. In addition to her recording career, Burrell is also known for her work as a television personality, having appeared on programs such as BET's "Celebration of Gospel" and the Daytime Emmy Award-winning "The 700 Club." Burrell is also an author and has written two books: "A Little More Jesus" and "Love's Burgeoning." In 2017, Burrell gained national attention when she made anti-LGBTQ comments during a sermon, leading to backlash and the cancellation of a planned performance on "The Ellen DeGeneres Show." After issuing an apology for her comments, Burrell continued to perform and release music. In early 2020, Burrell made headlines again when she was one of several high-profile pastors to be indicted in connection with a scheme involving a Houston-based nonprofit organization she controlled. Burrell could face up to 30 years in prison if convicted. 🎵🍂 ##### \_\_\_\_\_\_

LCS_segs: Ramesses IV (also known as Ramesses I) was the third pharaoh of the Twentieth Dynasty of Egypt in the New Kingdom.
He ruled from c. 1155 BC to 1150 BC.

His reign was notable for the rise of the royal palace's official, Bay, who became extremely powerful and may have influenced the succession of Ramesses IV to the throne, according to some historians.
Ramesses IV is also known for building works at the temple of Min at Koptos
for his victories over the Nubians in the region of Wawat.
He was eventually succeeded by his son Ramesses V.

bio: Paul Kruger (10 October 1825 – 14 July 1904) was a prominent 19th century Boer leader and politician. He served as the President of the South African Republic (Zuid-Afrikaansche Republiek) from 1883 to 1902, leading Boer forces against the British during the Second Boer War (1899–1902). Kruger was born on a farm in the southwestern Cape Colony, the son of a German farmer and a Limpopo woman of the Barolong tribe. He spent his early years on his family's homestead, where he received a basic education in reading and writing Dutch. Kruger became a successful farmer, becoming a successful farmer, breeder of fine horses, and a man of great influence in the southern Transvaal. Kruger served as the President of the South African Republic (Zuid-Afrikaansche Republiek), serving in that capacity for 18 years. Kruger was a passionate supporter of Boer independence, and he believed in the right of the Boers to self-governance. Kruger's presidency was marked by his desire to protect the rights of the Boers in a rapidly changing world. Kruger's leadership was marked by his desire to protect the rights of the Boers in a rapidly changing world.
